# Can The Accounting Firms Unseat Biglaw?
## Times are changing. Are law firms in trouble?
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onMay 10, 2019 at 3:15 PMMay 10, 2019 at 11:58 AM
58
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/05/can-the-accounting-firms-unseat-biglaw/&text=Can%20The%20Accounting%20Firms%20Unseat%20Biglaw?)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/05/can-the-accounting-firms-unseat-biglaw/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/05/can-the-accounting-firms-unseat-biglaw/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
A hot conversation started around the legal industry — an industry where the bar for the term “hot” is apparently pretty low — is if and when the Big 4 accounting firms will force their way into the American legal market. They have [some built-in advantages](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/02/twilight-of-the-law-firms-the-big-4-are-poised-to-conquer-the-legal-landscape/), especially when it comes to pre-existing relationships they can leverage into legal business. They’ve [made strides in Asia](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/08/asia-becomes-ground-zero-in-big-4-effort-to-take-over-the-legal-market/) and have started — haltingly — to make forays into the American market.

Of course, the accounting firms are prevented by existing ethical provisions from practicing law in U.S. jurisdictions. But how long will those rules hold up when the Big 4 decide to start throwing their weight around? Today, the behemoth entities set up “strategic partnerships” with existing law firms, agreeing to send their stockpiles of business to a partner firm. All the happy talk about “synergy” rests atop the idea of a proof of concept test run right under our noses.

Epstein Becker Green is the most recent strategic partner, joining up with Deloitte, but it’s just the latest in the line. From [Bloomberg Big Law Business](https://biglawbusiness.com/big-four-big-law-alliance-could-spur-more-partnerships):

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
This is not the first “strategic alliance” pairing a law firm with a Big Four firm. Last June, immigration law firm called Berry Appleman & Leiden entered into an alliance with the British arm of Deloitte, allowing the firm access to Deloitte’s worldwide customer base.

Three months later, PwC and the immigration firm Fragomen announced a partnership to provide tax and immigration services to clients and their employees.

[[Adam Smith Esq.’s](https://adamsmithesq.com) Bruce] MacEwen said deals like this are indicative of the fast changing nature of legal work as it expands outside the scope of traditional legal practices.

With a broad network of client relationships and decades upon decades of goodwill built up in other professional service sectors, the Big 4 appear an existential threat to a lot of law firms out there. Indeed, if the accounting firms entered full-fledged legal practice, they’d instantly be among the largest firms in the world. On the other hand, some industry insiders think size might not be a virtue. With competing stakeholders across other service sectors, they think a Big 4 legal practice would buckle under its own weight and fall behind more nimble, dedicated law firms.

It’s impossible to say how this will all turn out, but at this point, law firms don’t seem worried about the Big 4.

[Chuck Baldwin, a managing director with Ogletree Deakins] said he’s not concerned that Ogletree will be affected, as the firm has 950 lawyers located in 53 offices throughout the U.S. as well as international lawyers.

“We still feel really good about our competitive position,” he said. “For them to compete with us, they’d have to open 30 other offices in the U.S. alone.”

From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
Fair enough. Yet, the above quote reminds me of the conclusion of Arthur C. Clarke’s short story, Rescue Party. At the end of the tale of an advanced alien civilization taking pity on primitive humanity with our quaint nuclear-age technology:

“I wonder what they’ll be like?” he mused. “Will they be nothing but wonderful engineers, with no art or philosophy? They’re going to have such a surprise when Orostron reaches them—I expect it will be rather a blow to their pride. It’s funny how all isolated races think they’re the only people in the Universe. But they should be grateful to us; we’re going to save them a good many hundred years of travel.”
…
“Something tells me they’ll be very determined people,” he added. “We had better be polite to them. After all, we only outnumber them about a thousand million to one.”

Rugon laughed at his captain’s little joke.

Twenty years afterward, the remark didn’t seem funny.

Walgreens announced that it is expanding its specialty pharmacy offerings. Experts think that this move could yield several strategic benefits, given the higher profit margins associated with specialty medications compared to traditional drugs. They also think Walgreens’ move could lead to greater competition, consolidation, and innovation within the broader pharmacy industry.

onJuly 16, 2021 at 6:48 PMJuly 16, 2021 at 11:26 AM
1

According to data collected by the National Association for Law Placement, in 2020, which region in the U.S. had the highest level of lateral hiring per office?

Hint: In this region, there was a median of 6.5 and an average of 11.5 lateral hires last year, compared with medians of 3.0 to 4.5 in all other regions.

# The Am Law A-List: Ranking The Most Elite Law Firms In America (2020)
## Your firm may be elite, but is it among the best of the best? Find out here.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onAugust 6, 2020 at 12:12 PMAugust 6, 2020 at 11:31 AM
4
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/08/the-am-law-a-list-ranking-the-most-elite-law-firms-in-america-2020/&text=The%20Am%20Law%20A-List:%20Ranking%20The%20Most%20Elite%20Law%20Firms%20In%20America%20(2020))[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/08/the-am-law-a-list-ranking-the-most-elite-law-firms-in-america-2020/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/08/the-am-law-a-list-ranking-the-most-elite-law-firms-in-america-2020/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Another day, another ranking for lawyers to ogle in a search for meaning as they attempt to get through the day’s billables during a pandemic. Despite all the unrest and change in the world thanks to COVID-19, this is still the life of a Biglaw attorney, always on the hunt for confirmation that their firm is the best firm, the one that’s hitting all of its essential metrics year after year. If that sounds like you (and you might as well admit it, it probably does), then you should check out the latest offering from the American Lawyer, the annual A-List ranking.

Are you somehow unfamiliar with this ranking? Here are all of the metrics that it measures to determine which Biglaw firms are the best of the best:

The A-List recognizes firms based on a combination of factors, both financial and cultural: revenue per lawyer, pro bono commitment, associate satisfaction, racial diversity and gender diversity (the percentage of equity partners who are women), with RPL and pro bono given double weight. Each metric measures Am Law 200 firms’ relative performance—a firm’s score in a given category is based on its ranking among all 200 firms. Each category, as well as the overall score, is based on a 100-point scale.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
With that said, the full top 20 firms and their scores are listed at the [American Lawyer](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2020/08/05/the-2020-a-list-amid-upheaval-firms-focus-on-finding-balance/). Without further ado, here are the top 10 to satiate your rankings cravings (with the firms’ total scores noted parenthetically):

1. Munger Tolles (92.8)
2. Ropes & Gray (91.2)
3. O’Melveney (89.6)
4. Debevoise (89)
5. Orrick (87.5)
6. Covington (86.4)
7. Paul Weiss (86)
8. Paul Hastings (85.6)
9. WilmerHale (85.5)
10. Skadden (84.7)

Congratulations to all of the firms that made this year’s Am Law A-List.

[The 2020 A-List: Amid Upheaval, Firms Focus on Finding Balance](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2020/08/05/the-2020-a-list-amid-upheaval-firms-focus-on-finding-balance/) [American Lawyer]

# Top Biglaw Firm Spreads The Season Cheer With Bonuses (And More)!
## Big money big money big money!
By [Chris Williams](https://abovethelaw.com/author/cwilliams/)  
onNovember 29, 2023 at 3:32 PMNovember 29, 2023 at 3:46 PM
2
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/11/top-biglaw-firm-spreads-the-season-cheer-with-bonuses-and-more/&text=Top%20Biglaw%20Firm%20Spreads%20The%20Season%20Cheer%20With%20Bonuses%20(And%20More)!)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/11/top-biglaw-firm-spreads-the-season-cheer-with-bonuses-and-more/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/11/top-biglaw-firm-spreads-the-season-cheer-with-bonuses-and-more/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Have you spent the last few weeks agonizing over if your firm will increase your salary? If you work at Dechert, fret no longer!

And with $1,288,692,000 in gross revenue last year, the firm can definitely afford sharing the wealth with their employees.

Here are the bonuses:



Those who managed to bill 2200 client billable hours are eligible for an additional 30% above the year-end bonus. If that weren’t enough, the folks that billed 2400 and over are eligible for an additional 40%! Who needs Netflix when you have paystubs like that!

Oh, are you wondering about salary? Well, they matched that too.



Congrats on making the big bucks!

We like hearing about bonuses almost as much as you enjoy spending them. As soon as your firm’s memo comes out, please [email it to us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Bonus) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Bonus”) or text us (646-820-8477). Please include the memo if available. You can take a photo of the memo and send it via text or email if you don’t want to forward the original PDF or Word file.

And if you’d like to sign up for ATL’s Salary & Bonus Alerts, please scroll down and enter your email address in the box below this post. If you previously signed up for the bonus alerts, you don’t need to do anything. You’ll receive an email notification within minutes of each bonus announcement that we publish.

Chris Williams became a social media manager and assistant editor for Above the Law in June 2021. Prior to joining the staff, he moonlighted as a minor Memelord™ in the Facebook group [Law School Memes for Edgy T14s](https://www.facebook.com/photo/?fbid=10222912314148913&set=p.10222912314148913&opaqueCursor=AboVBPzRKh4loie1LupyI7ltSvsaUWxURlMk_338xXb_BPhzMNPHbWfVDUsOyUH1mfvHQ4Bsipef989J-V0OyqhMZzHPafTw49vttxDh_no8xymRSSUssmh47qTzHAc13R0wzk8nPhgSylnSAYcBNbHjYDqZDqy5r0f7PwzCZw9T-0cakKMIin3XI0O8R5H5OJGAu4kJjGPAoZpgL6woU9lwoHiAjxAwAlpmdlyt6vHLJ1TVn2srkC3G4qBW5ANthJ_YNT3BUPCu2vu1ZIxiqYwXGLfMIxQR4cllUaB0Cja74ln1FHs3n-xyHe6MDtxln0-F4QJchox9nCaivB_xmSxw3FduERhPebhWj1MKJ20jeucGZ64jY6DdUn2d87dVgNlFE5qHvNEtfMpoEKx1096oFfqbZ9s71YVsbXxLIsRiiW54eLp4R7z3WHAKu8v8xeLIZt86UVU1iOaSlJ0n5tT3_VonQT6n2F0sIUSLY272cI-yjWxaUIr0Qj-1NQDFFcn9dkq8pYV2-o0M3LK2Qhr9LKt-Bk4MTGUZCkb4Kw6mgDmRCux3nhJqd2hdLd8LgTA).  He endured Missouri long enough to graduate from Washington University in St. Louis School of Law. He is a former boatbuilder who cannot swim, [a published author on critical race theory, philosophy, and humor](https://www.academia.edu/33296970/Lets_Be_Frank_Parrhesia_and_the_Black_Comedic_Tradition), and has a love for cycling that occasionally annoys his peers. You can reach him by email at [cwilliams@abovethelaw.com](mailto:cwilliams@abovethelaw.com) and by tweet at [@WritesForRent](https://twitter.com/WritesForRent).

# Morning Docket: 06.18.19
## * A survey of what mental health initiatives look like across the legal industry. It may not be great, but it's better than the mental health initiatives of a decade ago which amounted to, "we're comping your dinner, quit your whining." [[Law.com](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2019/06/17/law-firms-tackle-mental-health-one-initiative-at-a-time/)] * [Porn star Ella Hughes](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/09/woman-abandons-law-degree-to-become-porn-star/) (don't worry, these links are safe for work) has completed her law degree -- but not after having to face a lot of abuse from classmates. [[Legal Cheek](https://www.legalcheek.com/2019/06/student-turned-porn-star-quit-llb-after-being-bombarded-with-online-abuse/)] * Alex Jones is not having a great week -- what with all the child porn and the threatening lawyers stuff. [[The Wrap](https://www.thewrap.com/alex-jones-accused-of-threatening-lawyer-for-sandy-hook-families-after-child-porn-found-in-discovery-materials/)] * Speaking of conspiracy theory-spinning talk show hosts, Brett Kavanaugh's now quoting Dennis Prager in SCOTUS opinions. Cool cool. [[Alternet](https://www.alternet.org/2019/06/legal-scholar-tracks-down-the-bizarre-origins-of-the-right-wing-phrase-justice-kavanaugh-used-in-a-new-opinion/)] * The Wendy Moore gender discrimination suit against Jones Day appears to be over. Until the next one. [[The Recorder](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2019/06/17/former-jones-day-partner-drops-gender-discrimination-suit-against-firm/)] * Texas just killed a law that would have banned guns in airports because if you're going to strap yourself into a tin can at 30K feet, you may as well feel sheer terror on the ground too. [[Texas Tribune](https://www.texastribune.org/2019/06/17/abbott-veto-guns-in-airports-texas/)] * Judge threatens Shearman with ethics charges. [[Law360](https://www.law360.com/newyork/articles/1169662/shearman-threatened-with-ethics-referral-in-sunedison-mdl)]
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onJune 18, 2019 at 8:42 AM

# A&O Shearman To Move Into Shearman’s New York Office Space Post-Merger
## The legacy firm’s NYC office is beautiful, so this isn’t a shocking decision.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onJanuary 11, 2024 at 4:16 PMJanuary 17, 2024 at 11:47 AM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2024/01/ao-shearman-to-move-into-shearmans-new-york-office-space-post-merger/&text=A&O%20Shearman%20To%20Move%20Into%20Shearman’s%20New%20York%20Office%20Space%20Post-Merger)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2024/01/ao-shearman-to-move-into-shearmans-new-york-office-space-post-merger/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2024/01/ao-shearman-to-move-into-shearmans-new-york-office-space-post-merger/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Ed. note: Welcome to our daily feature, [Quote of the Day](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/quote-of-the-day/).

One of the exciting aspects of our combination is bringing our people together into a single office in each jurisdiction where we operate. [This approach] will accelerate our integration, foster collaboration and create powerful financial synergies on the real estate side.

— a statement from A&O Shearman on the soon-to-be combined firm’s decision to [take over](https://news.bloomberglaw.com/business-and-practice/a-o-shearman-to-adopt-shearman-space-in-nyc-move-in-london) Shearman & Sterling’s [recently renovated office in New York](https://abovethelaw.com/2022/11/shearman-sterlings-revamped-new-york-headquarters-sets-new-bar-for-legal-workplaces/) and occupy Allen & Overy’s current office in London before moving to a new office in 2027. “Whether we will be in the legacy Allen & Overy or legacy Shearman & Sterling space—or entirely new space—will vary by location,” the firm said. The firm’s goal is to finish all moves as soon as possible.

[Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/) is a senior editor at Above the Law, where she’s worked since 2011. She’d love to hear from you, so please feel free to [email](mailto:staci@abovethelaw.com) her with any tips, questions, comments, or critiques. You can follow her on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/stacizaretsky) and [Threads](https://www.threads.net/@stacizaretsky) or connect with her on [LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/in/staci-zaretsky).

# Equal Pay Pioneer Reflects On What It’s Like To Sue A Biglaw Firm
## Kerrie Campbell thinks it's everyone's responsibility to challenge blatant inequality.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onMay 4, 2018 at 1:45 PMMay 4, 2018 at 1:31 PM
30
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/05/equal-pay-pioneer-reflects-on-what-its-like-to-sue-a-biglaw-firm/&text=Equal%20Pay%20Pioneer%20Reflects%20On%20What%20It’s%20Like%20To%20Sue%20A%20Biglaw%20Firm)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/05/equal-pay-pioneer-reflects-on-what-its-like-to-sue-a-biglaw-firm/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/05/equal-pay-pioneer-reflects-on-what-its-like-to-sue-a-biglaw-firm/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

Kerrie Campbell

Even if you don’t remember the name [Kerrie Campbell](https://www.kcamlaw.com/about/), chances are you’ve read a story ([or two or three](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/kerrie-campbell/)) about her. She is the former Chadbourne & Parke partner who took the world of Biglaw by storm when [she sued her firm over a gender pay gap](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/08/biglaw-firm-hit-with-100-million-class-action-gender-discrimination-lawsuit/).

Styled as a purported class action, the case took on a total of three named plaintiffs [before it was settled](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/03/biglaw-firm-to-pay-over-3-million-to-settle-pay-discrimination-case/). Chadbourne, the firm Campbell sued, no longer exists — it was swallowed up [in a merger with Norton Rose,](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/02/biglaw-merger-means-the-end-of-chadbourne-parke/) but her experience taking on some of the best in the legal profession is illuminating. I recently had the opportunity to speak with Campbell, and she was happy to shine the light on what it is like to call out a Biglaw firm in court.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
Initially, I wanted to find out from Campbell what is was like the moment she realized she believed she was being paid less than her male counterparts. Campbell said she first had an inkling something was wrong with her compensation way back in her first year as a lateral partner. The firm circulated a year-end ranking of partner compensation — revealing the pecking order as it were — and given the amount of work she’d been billing she just knew something was wrong — a “shocking revelation” was how Campbell characterized it. And it was a real eye opening moment for Campbell as a lateral partner with 30 years of Biglaw experience and a solid book of business.

Campbell said she made the decision to sue her former firm when she realized merely leaving the firm or just complaining about it would never be enough to move the needle. Year after year [studies and reports](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/04/theres-a-27-percent-global-gender-pay-gap-for-equity-partners/) detailing the [gender pay gap](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/gender-pay-gap/) in the legal industry are published but little changes; Campbell asked herself “what am I going to do about it?” That question forced Campbell’s hand, in a manner of speaking, and she knew she had little choice but to file a lawsuit against her firm.

As one might imagine, the reality of litigating against a giant law firm is stressful — and even seasoned litigators noted how contentious this suit was. As a trial lawyer herself, Campbell said she wasn’t surprised at the way the suit went down. She says the way defendants in discrimination cases tend to react to a lawsuit is largely predictable and that was something she was ready for. But the way that her local professional community reacted to the lawsuit was a little surprising. Campbell said that, for the most part, professional colleagues in D.C. were hesitant to discuss, or even acknowledge, the case while it was ongoing. But interestingly, the converse was also true. People she’d never met from around the country reached out to Campbell expressing their support and letting her know they were rooting for her. Through it all Campbell says she has no regrets about filing the lawsuit.

Campbell believes there is more than just a culture of secrecy regarding the inner working of firms — including partner compensation — that allows a gender pay gap to exist. In fact, she says there is a “laundry list” of factors that keep it alive. One of the biggest issues she identifies is the one/two punch of complacency and silence. There is so much at risk for women at law firms, and they are so busy growing their own practice, they have little time to worry about the broader issue of a gender pay gap. But Campbell says acceptance of the status quo is unacceptable, and women need to speak up, support those who do, and challenge blatant inequality.

There are, however, structural barriers that sometimes prevent women from openly challenging the existing system. One of the biggest issues Campbell sees on that front is the existence of mandatory arbitration clauses — in employment or partnership agreements. This often means that even if a women is courageous enough to bring the issue to her employer’s attention, no one knows about it and there is no public debate (or accountability) about the firm’s practices. Campbell is a litigator at heart, and she believes access to courts (and the accompanying judicial scrutiny) is key for real change.

These days Campbell has left the world of Biglaw behind. She’s building [her own firm](https://www.kcamlaw.com/about/) and is excited to represent clients in a variety of matters. One of the most interesting representations she has is working with the legal defense fund for Time’s Up!, and she continues to be a passionate advocate for gender equality in the workplace. This seems like the perfect next chapter for an equal pay pioneer.

# Biglaw Senior Associate Killed In Avalanche During Ski Trip
## He was airlifted from the mountain, but pronounced dead at the hospital.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onFebruary 4, 2020 at 11:14 AMFebruary 4, 2020 at 9:59 AM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/02/biglaw-senior-associate-killed-in-avalanche-during-ski-trip/&text=Biglaw%20Senior%20Associate%20Killed%20In%20Avalanche%20During%20Ski%20Trip)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/02/biglaw-senior-associate-killed-in-avalanche-during-ski-trip/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/02/biglaw-senior-associate-killed-in-avalanche-during-ski-trip/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

(Image via Getty)

Today brings us unfortunate news from Japan, where a Freshfields attorney was killed in an avalanche during a backcountry ski trip. [Barnaby Levy](https://www.linkedin.com/in/barnaby-levy-b1b48090?originalSubdomain=hk), 34, was a senior associate with firm who advised corporations and financial institutions throughout the Asia-Pacific region on transactional tax issues.

The [South China Morning Post](https://www.scmp.com/news/asia/east-asia/article/3048729/british-lawyer-who-worked-hong-kong-dies-japan-avalanche) has additional information:

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  

Barnaby Levy (Image via LinkedIn)

Levy was backcountry skiing with his brother and a local guide on the southern flank of 703-metre-high Mount Pinneshiri in the town of Nakatombetsu, in northwest Hokkaido, when the avalanche struck around 11:30am on Saturday.

Local emergency services responded to reports that a group had been caught in an avalanche and scrambled a helicopter to recover Levy from the mountainside and transfer him to a nearby hospital, national broadcaster NHK reported. Levy was pronounced dead a short while after being admitted.

Levy’s brother and the guide both survived. An avalanche warning for Mount Pinneshiri had been issued due to “unseasonably warm winter conditions,” but Levy and his brother went on an off-piste ski route nonetheless. According to local media, now an investigation has been opened into why they went ahead with those plans.

The firm released the following statement upon receiving news of the senior associate’s death: “Barnaby Levy was a wonderful colleague, friend and lawyer. We are shocked and saddened by this news and he will be greatly missed. Our hearts go out to his family and many friends at this difficult time.”

We here at Above the Law extend our condolences to Barnaby Levy’s family, friends, and colleagues during these trying times.

### [ How Will Walgreens’ Expansion Into Specialty Pharmacy Affect The Industry? ](https://medcitynews.com/2024/04/walgreens-specialty-pharmacy-drugs/)
Walgreens announced that it is expanding its specialty pharmacy offerings. # The Comprehensive Partner's Guide To Associate Raises
## The essential guide every partner needs before handing out money.
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onJune 28, 2016 at 11:28 AMJune 28, 2016 at 4:23 PM
1
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/the-comprehensive-partners-guide-to-associate-raises/&text=The%20Comprehensive%20Partner’s%20Guide%20To%20Associate%20Raises)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/the-comprehensive-partners-guide-to-associate-raises/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/the-comprehensive-partners-guide-to-associate-raises/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
You’ve made partner. Congratulations. All your hard work has finally paid off.

But now all those annoying friends you used to have before you made the leap are clamoring for a raise. Somewhere in the back of your head you remember believing that associate raises were “good,” but that was before those raises came out of your paycheck. And now the rest of the partnership is turning to you for your thoughts on the spate of raises. What are you going to tell them?

Because we love you, we’ve created a handy cheatsheet to guide you through this process. If your firm is yet to raise salaries, be sure to take this to your next meeting.

Feel free to [email](mailto:joe@abovethelaw.com) any tips, questions, or comments. Follow him on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/josephpatrice) if you’re interested in law, politics, and a healthy dose of college sports news.

# Summer Associate Programs — And Pay — Cut Short Thanks To Coronavirus
## Sorry, law students. At this point, be thankful you still have jobs.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onApril 1, 2020 at 10:22 AMApril 2, 2020 at 1:15 PM
16
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/04/summer-associate-programs-and-pay-cut-short-thanks-to-coronavirus/&text=Summer%20Associate%20Programs%20—%20And%20Pay%20—%20Cut%20Short%20Thanks%20To%20Coronavirus)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/04/summer-associate-programs-and-pay-cut-short-thanks-to-coronavirus/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/04/summer-associate-programs-and-pay-cut-short-thanks-to-coronavirus/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

(Image via Getty)

It was just one week ago that many a Biglaw firm seemed confident that their summer associate programs would [go forward as originally planned](https://abovethelaw.com/2020/03/could-coronavirus-play-a-hand-in-biglaw-firms-canceling-summer-associate-programs/), despite the ongoing COVID-19 crisis. Perhaps there would be fewer festive outings and extravagant meals due to social distancing guidance, but some truly believed that things would be “just fine.” Others were more realistic, embracing the [possibility of remote work](https://abovethelaw.com/2020/03/biglaw-firms-cant-seem-to-decide-what-theyre-going-to-do-with-summer-associate-programs/) and even givng credence to delayed start dates. Now that firms have started announcing salary reductions, furloughs, and layoffs, the game has changed.

Which firms have decided to start their summer programs late — and pay their law student employees less?

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
First up is Cooley, which according to sources recently decided to cut its 10-week summer associate program back by four weeks. Law students will begin their work at the firm on June 15, and end their summers on July 24, as previously scheduled. We’re told that in addition to the firm’s deferred start date, law students’ paychecks will also come up a little short. Instead of receiving pay for the 10 weeks they were supposed to be working as detailed in their offer letters, Cooley summers will only receive pay for the length of their shortened programs.

Compare this to what’s going on at Sidley, where tipsters say summers will be starting their programs later than expected, on June 1, although the firm isn’t quite clear yet on how the program will operate (i.e., whether it will all remote or whether modifications will be made so in-person meetings can occur). Regardless of any possible abbreviated program length, we’ve heard that Sidley summers will be paid for the number of weeks indicated in their offer letters.

As more firms make strategic financial moves in the weeks to come, we suspect we’ll hear more about the fate of their summer associate programs. We sincerely hope that law students will receive the experiences — and pay — they were expecting to receive, but please bear in mind that the unexpected circumstances brought about the coronavirus outbreak could very well put an end to summer associate programs at some firms, so be thankful your job is still waiting for you.

Is your firm planning to hold its summer associate program as planned, despite coronavirus concerns? Please text us (646-820-8477) or [email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=Coronavirus%20Summer%20Associate%20Program) (subject line: “Coronavirus Summer Associate Program”) and let us know. Stay safe.

# The Largest Law Firm In The United States
## There's a new champion when it comes to law firm headcount.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onApril 16, 2018 at 11:48 AMApril 20, 2018 at 11:13 AM
36
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/04/the-largest-law-firm-in-the-united-states/&text=The%20Largest%20Law%20Firm%20In%20The%20United%20States)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/04/the-largest-law-firm-in-the-united-states/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/04/the-largest-law-firm-in-the-united-states/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

‘Your firm is HUGE!’

Ever since the recession hit, law schools have enrolled and graduated fewer and fewer students, and the legal profession as a whole took a major hit, having lost about 500,000 to 600,000 jobs that may never return. But despite the layoffs en masse that were a toll of the recession, the biggest of Biglaw firms are still employing thousands and thousands of attorneys — and they’ve been quickly growing in size.

But which U.S. Biglaw firm is the biggest of them all? [Law 360](https://www.law360.com/corporate/articles/1032583/law360-reveals-400-largest-us-firms) (sub. req.) can help us answer that question. Last night, the website released its master list of the top 400 law firms in the U.S. by headcount, and revealed that Jones Day, President Donald Trump’s go-to law firm, is [no longer the largest firm](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/03/whats-the-biggest-law-firm-in-the-country/) in the country. Not only did Jones Day lose 33 spots in [Above the Law’s 2018 Power 100](https://abovethelaw.com/law-firm-rankings/top-law-firms/) rankings, but the firm was bounced down to fourth place in the latest Law360 400 rankings — SAD!

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
The firm that now resides in the No. 1 spot is Kirkland & Ellis, which expanded its attorney headcount in America by about 13 percent in 2017. Kirkland is now the largest law firm to ever take the top spot in the Law360 400 ranking.

Below, you’ll find a list of the Top 10 largest law firms in the country by headcount:

1. Kirkland & Ellis: 1,854 U.S. attorneys
2. Latham & Watkins: 1,744 U.S. attorneys
3. Greenberg Traurig: 1,725 U.S. attorneys
4. Jones Day: 1,701 U.S. attorneys
5. Sidley Austin: 1,657 U.S. attorneys
6. Morgan Lewis: 1,652 U.S. attorneys
7. Skadden: 1,475 U.S. attorneys
8. DLA Piper: 1,427 U.S. attorneys
9. Lewis Brisbois: 1,201 U.S. attorneys
10. Holland & Knight: 1,180 U.S. attorneys

Click [here](https://www.law360.com/corporate/articles/1032583/law360-reveals-400-largest-us-firms) to see the full list of the 400 largest law firms in the country.

# Thoughts From A Biglaw Firm's Leader On Mandatory COVID Vaccination
## To encourage or require vaccination, that is the question at this Biglaw firm.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onFebruary 25, 2021 at 3:15 PMFebruary 25, 2021 at 2:59 PM
6
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/02/thoughts-from-a-biglaw-firms-leader-on-mandatory-covid-vaccination/&text=Thoughts%20From%20A%20Biglaw%20Firm’s%20Leader%20On%20Mandatory%20COVID%20Vaccination)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/02/thoughts-from-a-biglaw-firms-leader-on-mandatory-covid-vaccination/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/02/thoughts-from-a-biglaw-firms-leader-on-mandatory-covid-vaccination/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
I would hope that if the firm did what it needs to do to encourage our people—because we share a commitment to the firm and each other—that they would do that once it’s generally available and absolutely safe and there’s no other issues.

I hope we don’t get there. I think we can do it from an encouragement point of view.

— Winston & Strawn chairman [Thomas Fitzgerald](https://www.winston.com/en/who-we-are/professionals/fitzgerald-thomas-p.html), in comments given about [encouraging employees to receive COVID-19 vaccinations](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2021/02/25/dla-piper-winston-strawn-leaders-will-encourage-vaccines-for-returning-employees/), during a roundtable discussion on the future of the law firm office. Although he’d prefer encouragement to be enough, Fitzgerald said he’s still not ruling out mandating vaccination for a return to the office.

# Scuttlebutt Central: Legal Gossip Blogs
By [David Lat](https://abovethelaw.com/author/david-lat/)  
onNovember 2, 2006 at 12:52 PM
0
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2006/11/scuttlebutt-central-legal-gossip-blogs/&text=Scuttlebutt%20Central:%20Legal%20Gossip%20Blogs)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2006/11/scuttlebutt-central-legal-gossip-blogs/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2006/11/scuttlebutt-central-legal-gossip-blogs/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
If you haven’t already done so, we recommend that you read [this article](http://www.abanet.org/journal/redesign/11as.html) (and not just ’cause we’re featured in it). It’s entitled Scuttlebutt Central, by Stephanie Francis Ward, and it’s from the November 2006 issue of the [ABA Journal](http://www.abanet.org/journal/redesign/home.html).
The piece is a fun and interesting read; check it out for yourself. We’ll just comment on one passage that caught our eye:

A Washington, D.C., corporate associate who asked to remain anonymous admits to reading legal gossip blogs daily — a habit he says isn’t unusual among his peers.

“There’s an allure of some of these stories — like the summer associate in New York who took off her clothes and jumped into the Hudson River — so there’s sort of a universal appeal,” he says.

Allow us to supplement the record. According to [various](http://ourtakeonwake.blogspot.com/2005_07_01_ourtakeonwake_archive.html) [reports](http://cublawg.blogspot.com/2005/06/summer-associates.html), the summer associate in question was at the venerable firm of [Cleary, Gottlieb, Steen & Hamilton](http://www.cgsh.com/). The incident took place at a charity benefit held at the [Chelsea Piers](http://www.chelseapiers.com/) sports and entertainment complex. It turned out to be a fairly big deal because the SA had to be fished out of the river (either by the Coast Guard or an NYPD police boat).
We’re not sure if she ended up getting an offer. But given what a summer associate has to do NOT to get an offer — e.g., first- or second-degree murder (manslaughter, no big deal) — we wouldn’t be surprised if she did.
More juicy details [here](http://ourtakeonwake.blogspot.com/2005_07_01_ourtakeonwake_archive.html) and [here](http://cublawg.blogspot.com/2005/06/summer-associates.html).
[Scuttlebutt Central: Legal gossip blogs appeal to a nation of associates hungry for the local scoop](http://www.abanet.org/journal/redesign/11as.html) [ABA Journal]
[Summer Stories](http://ourtakeonwake.blogspot.com/2005_07_01_ourtakeonwake_archive.html) [What’s Up With Wake Law?]
[Summer Associates](http://cublawg.blogspot.com/2005/06/summer-associates.html) [CU bLAWg]

# What Lawyers Need To Know About Infrastructure And Construction Projects
## PLI’s one-day program is ideal for anyone working in the construction and infrastructure space.
By STEPHANIE WILKINS  
onJune 24, 2022 at 1:47 PMJune 24, 2022 at 12:52 PM
8
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/06/what-lawyers-need-to-know-about-infrastructure-and-construction-projects/&text=What%20Lawyers%20Need%20To%20Know%20About%20Infrastructure%20And%20Construction%20Projects)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/06/what-lawyers-need-to-know-about-infrastructure-and-construction-projects/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/06/what-lawyers-need-to-know-about-infrastructure-and-construction-projects/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
In recent years, the U.S. has seen an increased demand for more and better infrastructure. The uptick in interest in these kinds of projects is falling squarely on the shoulders of the construction industry and its lawyers.

In order to meet the rising demand and remain competitive in the national legal market, construction lawyers need to hone their expertise in infrastructure regulation, funding, and process. Without this knowledge, developers and contractors will struggle to succeed on large infrastructure projects.    

PLI is offering a one-day program, [Construction Projects and Infrastructure 2022](https://www.pli.edu/programs/construction-projects-and-infrastructure?t=live&tCode=CNS2_ATL01&utm_source=ATL01&utm_medium=DISPLAY&utm_campaign=CNS2), which features distinguished Program Chairs Josh M. Leavitt and Heidi Hennig Rowe, who will share their expertise on successful contracting, recent financing, and project management strategies in the construction and development space. The panel will also help explain to practitioners the heightened interest of lawmakers in the construction and engineering sectors, the important (and often unique) aspects of government contracts, and more.

Additional topics to be covered include:

- Key points of the recently passed Infrastructure Bill, Airport development, and Transit-Oriented Development (TOD)
- Project and public finance techniques including TIFIA and RRIF programs
- How to utilize meaningful stakeholders support and smart partner selection
- An in-depth explanation of Federal Acquisition Regulation (FAR)-based and other government contracts
- How to select the most effective delivery system 
- How to align project risks with financing risks
- Successful strategies for large contract projects
PLI’s program is ideal for anyone working in the construction and infrastructure space, including outside counsel, in-house attorneys, construction contract procurement professionals, and government agency officers. A background in federal construction contracts procurement, and real estate development will be beneficial. [Register today](https://www.pli.edu/programs/construction-projects-and-infrastructure?t=live&tCode=CNS2_ATL01&utm_source=ATL01&utm_medium=DISPLAY&utm_campaign=CNS2) to learn more.

# Did A Biglaw Partner Get Forced Out For Slapping An Associate When She Rejected His Advances?
## This is an outrageous story.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onMarch 29, 2018 at 2:45 PMMarch 29, 2018 at 4:30 PM
14
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/03/did-a-biglaw-partner-get-forced-out-for-slapping-an-associate-when-she-rejected-his-advances/&text=Did%20A%20Biglaw%20Partner%20Get%20Forced%20Out%20For%20Slapping%20An%20Associate%20When%20She%20Rejected%20His%20Advances?)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/03/did-a-biglaw-partner-get-forced-out-for-slapping-an-associate-when-she-rejected-his-advances/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/03/did-a-biglaw-partner-get-forced-out-for-slapping-an-associate-when-she-rejected-his-advances/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
The [#metoo](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/metoo/) sexual harassment scandals keep piling up, and the legal industry — always a little bit late, but not one to abandon trends entirely — has gotten onboard. The latest scandal, [reported as a blind item in RollOnFriday](http://www.rollonfriday.com/TheNews/EuropeNews/tabid/58/Id/5611/fromTab/36/currentIndex/0/Default.aspx), involves allegations against a London-based partner at a Magic Circle firm forced out of his firm following a jaw-dropping incident.

Read the details below then circle back for the outrage:

A Magic Circle partner was forced to quit his firm after he slapped an associate because she rejected his sexual advances.

The man, who is based in London and who RollOnFriday shall name ‘Slappo’, was rejected by his new firm when it found out, but then eventually found a new job at a third firm.

Last year he propositioned a junior female lawyer in his team. When she refused to succumb to his charms, said multiple sources, he slapped her in the face. She reported the matter to the firm which, after an investigation last Autumn, asked him to leave the partnership.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
Ya think? Hell, making unwanted sexual advances on a subordinate is probably more than enough — or should be more than enough — to lead to Slappo’s ouster from the firm. But raising the stakes of the altercation to the level of physical f**king violence? That is beyond “inappropriate.” That’s assault.

According to RollOnFriday, Slappo apparently found work at another firm on his way out the door. [In a familiar tale](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/03/timesup-for-this-biglaw-partner-who-got-a-new-gig-after-being-quietly-pushed-out-of-his-old-firm/), the offer was withdrawn once the details of the incident were revealed to the new firm. But don’t bother to shed any tears for Slappo, he supposedly found work at a third firm. Yes, sources report this third firm was made aware of the circumstances leading to Slappo’s departure from the original Magic Circle firm. But, really, what are a few slaps around the office when you’ve got someone who can make it rain?

[Exclusive: Magic Circle partner sacked for slapping associate](http://www.rollonfriday.com/TheNews/EuropeNews/tabid/58/Id/5611/fromTab/36/currentIndex/0/Default.aspx) [RollOnFriday]

###Sponsored
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)

# Book Of Business: A New Podcast From Above The Law
## If you're interested in the world of Biglaw, this is the podcast for you.
By [David Lat](https://abovethelaw.com/author/david-lat/)  
onMarch 5, 2018 at 3:46 PMJune 22, 2022 at 10:25 AM
6
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/03/book-of-business-a-new-podcast-from-above-the-law/&text=Book%20Of%20Business:%20A%20New%20Podcast%20From%20Above%20The%20Law)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/03/book-of-business-a-new-podcast-from-above-the-law/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/03/book-of-business-a-new-podcast-from-above-the-law/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
If you’re interested in the world of large law firms — and if you’re reading Above the Law, you probably are — then we have the podcast for you.

Following up on the success of our first podcast, [Thinking Like A Lawyer](https://legaltalknetwork.com/podcasts/thinking-like-a-lawyer/), we’ve decided to launch a second. It’s called [Book of Business](http://atlbookofbusiness.libsyn.com/), brought to you by ATL and our friends at [Kinney Recruiting](http://www.kinneyrecruiting.com/).

Book of Business is hosted by myself and veteran legal recruiter Robert Kinney, Founder and President of Kinney Recruiting (sponsor of the podcast). In each episode, Robert and I will do three things. First, we’ll analyze a recent notable lateral move or collection of moves, explaining their significance for the Biglaw world. Second, we’ll take an in-depth look at a specific legal market, discussing what it’s like to practice in that market, including its pros and cons. Finally, we’ll offer career advice for the audience of Book of Business — current and aspiring partners at leading law firms.

In the [first episode](http://atlbookofbusiness.libsyn.com/discussions-about-the-merger-between-andrews-kurth-and-hunton-williams-episode-1), we discuss [lateral moves](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/01/will-partner-poaching-stop-this-rumored-biglaw-merger-in-its-tracks/) related to the [recent merger](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/02/biglaw-merger-creates-new-1000-lawyer-firm/) between Andrews Kurth and Hunton & Williams; conduct a market snapshot of New York, the biggest Biglaw market; and offer advice to lawyers on the important topic of negotiating lateral offers.

Check out Book of Business via the embed or links below, and subscribe to future episodes through your podcast purveyor of choice. Enjoy!


[Biglaw Book of Business](http://atlbookofbusiness.libsyn.com/) [main website]
[Episode 1: The Merger Between Andrews Kurth and Hunton & Williams](http://atlbookofbusiness.libsyn.com/discussions-about-the-merger-between-andrews-kurth-and-hunton-williams-episode-1) [Book of Business]
[Biglaw Book of Business](https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/biglaw-book-of-business/id1354269858?mt=2) [iTunes]

Earlier: [Biglaw Merger Creates New 1,000 Lawyer Firm](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/02/biglaw-merger-creates-new-1000-lawyer-firm/)

[David Lat](https://abovethelaw.com/author/david-lat/) is editor at large and founding editor of Above the Law, as well as the author of [Supreme Ambitions: A Novel](http://bit.ly/2DTCG3D). He previously worked as a federal prosecutor in Newark, New Jersey; a litigation associate at Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz; and a law clerk to Judge Diarmuid F. O’Scannlain of the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit. You can connect with David on [Twitter (@DavidLat)](http://bit.ly/2BMTF1R), [LinkedIn](http://bit.ly/2E9v0tq), and [Facebook](http://bit.ly/2nxIENN), and you can reach him by email at [dlat@abovethelaw.com](mailto:dlat@abovethelaw.com).

####Topics
[Advice](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/advice/), [Andrews Kurth](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/andrews-kurth/), [Andrews Kurth Kenyon](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/andrews-kurth-kenyon/), [Andrews Kurth Kenyon LLP](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/andrews-kurth-kenyon-llp/), [Biglaw](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/biglaw/), [Book of Business](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/book-of-business/), [Career Advice](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/career-advice/), [Hunton & Williams](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/hunton-williams/), [Hunton Andrews Kurth](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/hunton-andrews-kurth/), [Kinney Recruiting](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/kinney-recruiting/), [Kinney Recruiting Above The Law](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/kinney-recruiting-above-the-law/), [Lateral Moves](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/lateral-moves/), [New York](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/new-york/), [New York City](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/new-york-city/), [Partner Issues](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/partner-issues/), [Robert Kinney](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/robert-kinney/), [Sponsored Content](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/sponsored-content/), [Texas](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/texas/)

### [ How Will Walgreens’ Expansion Into Specialty Pharmacy Affect The Industry? ](https://medcitynews.com/2024/04/walgreens-specialty-pharmacy-drugs/)

# On Thinking Versus Really Thinking
## If you'd like to develop a reputation as a competent person, you'll choose to think seriously about stuff. 
By [Mark Herrmann](https://abovethelaw.com/author/mark-herrmann/)  
onApril 8, 2019 at 9:59 AMApril 6, 2019 at 9:32 PM
13
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/04/on-thinking-versus-really-thinking/&text=On%20Thinking%20Versus%20Really%20Thinking)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/04/on-thinking-versus-really-thinking/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/04/on-thinking-versus-really-thinking/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
What do you think of that five-page memo on your desk?

Pick it up.  Flip through it.  Send back an email:  “This looks okay to me.”

Change tacks.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
Decide that there’s a typo in that five-page memo.

Pick up the memo.  Read it.  Search for the typo.

You didn’t find the typo.  Read the memo again, really looking for the typo.

Aha!  It’s right there, in the footnote on page four.

That’s the difference between skimming and focusing.

Try this experiment again.

Decide that the memo has a substantive error in it.  Read the memo with that thought in mind.

You didn’t find the substantive error.

So slow down.  Read the memo again.  Concentrate.  Think about the implications of every sentence.

###Sponsored
[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)

If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)

### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
Aha!  The substantive error is right there, in the third paragraph.  (It’s remarkable you didn’t catch this the last time around.)

Send your responsive email:  “The memo generally looks okay, but I have a question about the third paragraph.  We say . . . .  Also, note that there’s a typo on the second line of the footnote on page four.”

How do you suppose the recipient of that email — the boss or the partner — reacts?

I frankly think that the first type of thinking — not really thinking about things at all, but merely passing your eyes over stuff — is routine, in law, and business, and just about everywhere else.  After all, it’s easy not to think about things.  And, as to most stuff that crosses your desk, why should you think about it, anyway?  Not only that, but most things don’t deserve serious thought.

On the other hand, if you’d like to develop a reputation as a competent person, you’ll choose to think seriously about stuff.  

If you’re the one person in the crowd who catches errors, then who’s the boss likely to rely on next time?

If you’re the associate who makes contributions, and the other associates blow things off — figuring that the partner prepared the draft, so it’s probably fine — who will the partner go to for projects that count?

Perhaps it’s not worthwhile to think hard about every item that crosses your desk; that really depends on how many things, of what importance, are crossing your desk.

But if you improve your joint’s collective work product, while other people type back that drafts “look okay to them,” you’ll soon stand out from the crowd.

It would help, naturally, if you were very smart. 

But it would suffice if you simply paid attention — really paid attention — to projects that came your way.

Mark Herrmann spent 17 years as a partner at a leading international law firm and is now deputy general counsel at a large international company. He is the author of [The Curmudgeon’s Guide to Practicing Law](http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/1590316762/ref=as_li_ss_tl?ie=UTF8&tag=dealbreaker-20&linkCode=as2&camp=1789&creative=390957&creativeASIN=1590316762) and [Inside Straight: Advice About Lawyering, In-House And Out, That Only The Internet Could Provide](http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/1614385394/ref=as_li_ss_tl?ie=UTF8&camp=1789&creative=390957&creativeASIN=1614385394&linkCode=as2&tag=dealbreaker-20) (affiliate links). You can reach him by email at [inhouse@abovethelaw.com](mailto:inhouse@abovethelaw.com).

# Business Travel Amid The Pandemic: Are Lawyers Ready To Return To The Lives They Left?
## In true lawyerly fashion, it depends.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onOctober 8, 2021 at 1:13 PMOctober 8, 2021 at 12:46 PM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/10/business-travel-amid-the-pandemic-are-lawyers-ready-to-return-to-the-lives-they-left/&text=Business%20Travel%20Amid%20The%20Pandemic:%20Are%20Lawyers%20Ready%20To%20Return%20To%20The%20Lives%20They%20Left?)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/10/business-travel-amid-the-pandemic-are-lawyers-ready-to-return-to-the-lives-they-left/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/10/business-travel-amid-the-pandemic-are-lawyers-ready-to-return-to-the-lives-they-left/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
For more than 18 months now, lawyers and staff members have largely worked from home thanks to the pandemic. But with law firms now announcing (and postponing and then delaying) their offce reentry plans, the prospect of a commute looms large. And with a commute comes the expectation that other business travel may soon be expected as well.

With that in mind, it got us wondering: will attorneys truly be ready for more business travel once the new year rolls around?

We polled attorneys and staff members running the professional gamut across Biglaw firms, small firms, in-house legal departments, and state and federal government offices to find out what lies ahead for the legal workforce in the wake of the pandemic. The largest group of respondents to our survey were law firm partners and counsel (36.25%), followed by law firm associates (26.25%), and general counsel/in-house counsel (18.75%). Are lawyers ready to travel for business again? In true lawyerly fashion, it depends.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
The largest cohort of our survey respondents (27.85%) reported that they are planning moderately less travel in 2022 compared with their travel plans from before the pandemic, with 20.25% reporting that they will be doing far less travel. These responses were expected; after all, we’re still in a pandemic. Now, let’s get down to the nitty gritty.

How do your business travel plans for internal meetings in 2022 compare with those from before the pandemic?



The largest cohort of respondents (27.12%) reported that they are planning far less travel for internal meetings in 2022 compared with their travel plans from before the pandemic. Nothing unexpected here, folks.

How do your business travel plans for external/client meetings in 2022 compare with those from before the pandemic?



The largest cohort of respondents (30%) reported that they are planning moderately less travel for external/client meetings in 2022 compared with their travel plans from before the pandemic. The hits just keep on coming for business travel in 2022.

How do you feel about your amount of planned business travel for 2022?



###Sponsored
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
The largest cohort of respondents (30.43%) reported that they believe their amount of planned business travel for 2022 is the right amount. Who are these people who want to travel a lot more? Maybe the secret lies within the responses to our next survey question.

How important do you believe business travel will be to business development and client satisfaction?



Aha, here we go. The largest cohort of respondents (32.35%) reported that business travel is somewhat important to business development and client satisfaction. This thinking leads us to the reason why many law firms are trying to reopen before 2021 is over.

How important do you believe business travel will be to law firm morale, mentorship, and internal networking?



Over one third of respondents (36.76%) reported that they believed business travel is somewhat important to law firm morale, mentorship, and internal networking. But just saying, many associates value the health and safety of their families more than their law firm networking opportunities.

When asked to share their general thoughts on business travel in the future, our survey respondents really spoke their minds and some common themes emerged. Here are some select responses that we thought would really resonate with others.

- “The pandemic has demonstrated that plenty of business can be conducted just as easily and successfully virtually. As much as I enjoy seeing people in person, I am comfortable with NOT attending ANY in person conferences before 2023 (and I’ll reconsider that next summer).”
- “The pandemic shattered old models. From court hearings to meetings, it’s really a new (better) world. We don’t need to burn so much jet fuel and head downtown (or out of town) for every court appearance or meeting. Zoom works just fine.”
- “We’ve proven excessive business travel is not necessary for success. We owe it to our own health and well-being, and that of our planet, not to rush back to what we used to consider ‘normal.’ It never was, or at least never should have been.”
- “Remote depos work, remote meetings work. Business travel, for the most part, is a waste of time and resources.”
As it turns out, not everyone wants to remain at home forever. Here are some thoughts from other survey respondents who wish things could go back to the way they were before the pandemic.

- “We need to all get vaccinated and become comfortable meeting in person again. Meeting in person facilitates the exchange of useful information and ideas – which our world desperately needs more of right now – better than any videoconferencing platform.”
- “I wish business travel would return to pre-pandemic levels, but I do not think that will happen.”
- “Lawyers are incredibly risk averse and do not understand data and numbers. Being fully vaccinated and understanding how good the data is for those who are vaccinated, I plan to take advantage of that and get in front of clients more often than other attorneys.”
So there you have it. Are lawyers ready for business travel again? Yes! But also, no. As with all things having to do with COVID-19, plans for any travel are likely subject to some amount of change, so be sure to prepare yourselves for all the possibilities that go hand in hand with office life — because it’s going to start happening again, and sooner than you may like.

[Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/) is a senior editor at Above the Law, where she’s worked since 2011. She’d love to hear from you, so please feel free to [email](mailto:staci@abovethelaw.com) her with any tips, questions, comments, or critiques. You can follow her on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/stacizaretsky) or connect with her on [LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/in/staci-zaretsky).

# Biglaw Firm Gets In On The Associate Bonus Action
## Bonus season is officially underway!!
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onNovember 20, 2018 at 3:42 PMNovember 20, 2018 at 3:31 PM
15
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/11/biglaw-firm-gets-in-on-the-associate-bonus-action/&text=Biglaw%20Firm%20Gets%20In%20On%20The%20Associate%20Bonus%20Action)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/11/biglaw-firm-gets-in-on-the-associate-bonus-action/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/11/biglaw-firm-gets-in-on-the-associate-bonus-action/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
The really fun part of bonus season is here — it’s that time when we here at Above the Law start getting a deluge of tips from faithful readers excited that their time in the mines of Biglaw are being rewarded. Now we can add another firm to the (growing) list of Biglaw shops doing right by their associates and ponying up the big bucks (as [Cravath as defined](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/11/breaking-cravath-announces-annual-bonuses/) it a short day ago).

The latest entry onto the list of firms giving out market bonuses is Debevoise & Plimpton. In case you’ve some how forgotten just what that scale is, here is the bonus structure for you to enjoy:



[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)

Far from being Scrooges, it appears the holiday season has arrived early for these lucky associates.

(The full memo from the firm is on the next page.)

Please help us help you when it comes to bonus news at other firms. As soon as your firm’s bonus memo comes out, please [email it to us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Bonus) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Bonus”) or text us (646-820-8477). Please include the memo if available. You can take a photo of the memo and send it via text or email if you don’t want to forward the original PDF or Word file.

And if you’d like to sign up for ATL’s Bonus Alerts, please scroll down and enter your email address in the box below this post. If you previously signed up for the bonus alerts, you don’t need to do anything. You’ll receive an email notification within minutes of each bonus announcement that we publish.

# Landlord Begs Law Firm To Stop 'Toilet Abuse'
## I don't know exactly what "toilet abuse" is, but it's nothing good.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onAugust 11, 2022 at 11:43 AMAugust 11, 2022 at 11:16 AM
11
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/08/landlord-begs-law-firm-to-stop-toilet-abuse/&text=Landlord%20Begs%20Law%20Firm%20To%20Stop%20‘Toilet%20Abuse’)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/08/landlord-begs-law-firm-to-stop-toilet-abuse/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/08/landlord-begs-law-firm-to-stop-toilet-abuse/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Even multinational law firms with 1500+ attorneys in nine countries have to deal with the vagaries of the human condition. Don’t believe me? Take a look at an unfortunate incident taking place in the Birmingham, UK, location of Gowling WLG.

Building management posted the following[ notice](https://www.rollonfriday.com/sites/default/files/inline-images/poo%20sign.jpg) — as [reported by](https://www.rollonfriday.com/news-content/excloosive-gowling-wlg-told-address-toilet-abuse) Roll on Friday — asking, nay, begging that “toilet abuse” on the floors occupied by the firm cease immediately.

Important Notice
Toilet Abuse

We are experiencing some very unhygienic toilet abuse. We would ask the person carrying out this abuse to stop this unacceptable behaviour immediately.

This has been reported to the Occupiers Senior Management who occupy these floors.

This is a Health and Safety issue for users of the facilities and the cleaning team that are having attend [sic] each incident.

Building Management

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
While the definition of “toilet abuse” is left in the minds of the beholder (and the firm has not commented on the incident(s)), it is pretty clear that whatever’s going on is both gross and unacceptable. Let’s just hope they can dispose of the matter quickly.

Kathryn Rubino is a Senior Editor at Above the Law, host of [The Jabot podcast](https://open.spotify.com/show/1XC11QhFCWxWr4NQrk2sEA), and co-host of [Thinking Like A Lawyer](https://legaltalknetwork.com/podcasts/thinking-like-a-lawyer/). AtL tipsters are the best, so please connect with her. Feel free to email [her](mailto:kathryn@abovethelaw.com?subject=Your%20Column) with any tips, questions, or comments and follow her on Twitter ([@Kathryn1](//twitter.com/Kathryn1%22)).

# Legal Sector Lost 4K+ Jobs In January, But There's No Need To Worry
## The legal job market is 'cyclical,' says one top recruiter, and today's lob losses will turn into tomorrow's job gains.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onFebruary 5, 2024 at 1:47 PM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2024/02/legal-sector-lost-4k-jobs-in-january-but-theres-no-need-to-worry/&text=Legal%20Sector%20Lost%204K+%20Jobs%20In%20January,%20But%20There’s%20No%20Need%20To%20Worry)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2024/02/legal-sector-lost-4k-jobs-in-january-but-theres-no-need-to-worry/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2024/02/legal-sector-lost-4k-jobs-in-january-but-theres-no-need-to-worry/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

(Image via Getty)

Ed. note: Welcome to our daily feature, [Quote of the Day](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/quote-of-the-day/).

The demand for legal services in different practice areas is cyclical. I have no doubt that the demand for legal services will continue to climb. The practices touched by that demand will change overtime. As the type of legal services needed by businesses change there will be a transition, reflected as job losses in some practices followed by hiring in other practices, as firms adjust their talent mix to service their clients.

— [David Maurer](https://www.mlaglobal.com/en/people/david-maurer?byconsultantorauthor=david-maurer), executive director for legal search and recruiting firm Major Lindsey & Africa’s partner practice group, in comments given to [Law360 Pulse](https://www.law360.com/legalindustry/articles/1789356/us-legal-sector-drops-4-400-jobs-in-january), concerning the Labor Department’s latest report showing that the U.S. legal sector lost 4,400 jobs in January. Maurer went on to note that compared to the same time frame last year, he’d seen an increase in requests for lawyers over the last three months, ending January 31.

[Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/) is a senior editor at Above the Law, where she’s worked since 2011. She’d love to hear from you, so please feel free to [email](mailto:staci@abovethelaw.com) her with any tips, questions, comments, or critiques. You can follow her on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/stacizaretsky) and [Threads](https://www.threads.net/@stacizaretsky) or connect with her on [LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/in/staci-zaretsky).

By [Chris Williams](https://abovethelaw.com/author/cwilliams/)

(photo by David Lat).

In unexpected news to legal nerds everywhere, there has been a major shakeup in the makeup of Kirkland & Ellis over the Second Amendment. Paul Clement’s work moves [just have a way of being newsworthy](https://abovethelaw.com/2011/04/paul-clement-quits-king-spalding-after-ks-moves-to-drop-doma-defense/), don’t they?

"Paul and Erin have been valued colleagues,” said Jon A. Ballis, Chairman of Kirkland’s Executive Committee. “We wish them the best of luck in the future and we look forward to collaborating with them in the future in matters not involving the Second Amendment.”

— Alison Frankel (@AlisonFrankel) [June 23, 2022](https://twitter.com/AlisonFrankel/status/1540049072484229121?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw)

For those of you who aren’t in the legal know, this metaphor may help you get how massive this is.

Tom Brady of gun lawyers leaves top law firm [https://t.co/HCZiWSnnl1](https://t.co/HCZiWSnnl1)

— Spencer Smith (@spencer429) [June 23, 2022](https://twitter.com/spencer429/status/1540052963007385600?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw)

That not doing it? Try these on for size. This is like:

- Wu-Tang becoming something to mess with.
- Left Twix tasting different from Right Twix.
- The right to gun ownership being in relationship to the requirements of a well-regulated militia.

[Joe has made the point in the past](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/08/paul-weiss-touts-anti-death-penalty-reputation-so-why-is-the-firm-helping-oklahoma-kill-a-man/) that the “everyone deserves a lawyer” argument is going out of vogue. Sure, everybody wants to be filthy rich — [like so filthy rich you have to put shoe coverings on before you walk about the house](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=CKEMGr07BMk) — but in a woke culture like ours, firms need to consider their branding in addition to their practice. Being associated with school shootings, far beyond being unethical, may impact the bottom line, after all! While it’s anyone’s guess if this falling out was fundamentally about morals or money, it definitely looks like Kirkland decided making bazillions doing private equity is preferable to constantly getting written up in the media as the NRA Hypebeasts trying to make murdering schoolchildren easier.

Chris Williams became a social media manager and assistant editor for Above the Law in June 2021. Prior to joining the staff, he moonlighted as a minor Memelord™ in the Facebook group [Law School Memes for Edgy T14s](https://www.facebook.com/photo/?fbid=10222912314148913&set=p.10222912314148913&opaqueCursor=AboVBPzRKh4loie1LupyI7ltSvsaUWxURlMk_338xXb_BPhzMNPHbWfVDUsOyUH1mfvHQ4Bsipef989J-V0OyqhMZzHPafTw49vttxDh_no8xymRSSUssmh47qTzHAc13R0wzk8nPhgSylnSAYcBNbHjYDqZDqy5r0f7PwzCZw9T-0cakKMIin3XI0O8R5H5OJGAu4kJjGPAoZpgL6woU9lwoHiAjxAwAlpmdlyt6vHLJ1TVn2srkC3G4qBW5ANthJ_YNT3BUPCu2vu1ZIxiqYwXGLfMIxQR4cllUaB0Cja74ln1FHs3n-xyHe6MDtxln0-F4QJchox9nCaivB_xmSxw3FduERhPebhWj1MKJ20jeucGZ64jY6DdUn2d87dVgNlFE5qHvNEtfMpoEKx1096oFfqbZ9s71YVsbXxLIsRiiW54eLp4R7z3WHAKu8v8xeLIZt86UVU1iOaSlJ0n5tT3_VonQT6n2F0sIUSLY272cI-yjWxaUIr0Qj-1NQDFFcn9dkq8pYV2-o0M3LK2Qhr9LKt-Bk4MTGUZCkb4Kw6mgDmRCux3nhJqd2hdLd8LgTA).  He endured Missouri long enough to graduate from Washington University in St. Louis School of Law. He is a former boatbuilder who cannot swim, [a published author on critical race theory, philosophy, and humor](https://www.academia.edu/33296970/Lets_Be_Frank_Parrhesia_and_the_Black_Comedic_Tradition), and has a love for cycling that occasionally annoys his peers. You can reach him by email at [cwilliams@abovethelaw.com](mailto:cwilliams@abovethelaw.com) and by tweet at [@WritesForRent](https://twitter.com/WritesForRent).
