From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
Before I heard of Jack Chen, if you told me of a totally blind lawyer working at the very highest levels of the profession, I would have believed it—while waiting for the other shoe to drop. That is, I would have expected to hear of some new technological invention that was making the practice of law more feasible for the blind lawyer. To some degree, I think that’s how we are programmed to think now. Perhaps it’s the fact that inventions are coming at us with such frequency. Perhaps it is the hysteric attention given to new product releases (iPhone 7, anyone?). Perhaps it’s something else entirely. Whatever the reason, the fact remains that we’re accustomed to seeking answers to our problems and needs in new technologies and in new inventions.

But innovation and invention are two different things.

Watching the report, I was taken with the fact that Jack’s solutions to the obstacles he faces seemed to involve well-understood technology, adapted for Jack, but widely available. For instance, his technique for inhaling unbelievable amounts of information—letting him read at a pace of 620 words per minute—relies on nothing more exotic than text-to-voice technology and a fast-forward button. I hope Jack doesn’t mind me saying that his brand of innovation appears to owe more to MacGyver than Steve Jobs. Make no mistake, that’s a compliment. It’s impressive to see him using just his own creativity and already-existing tools to so greatly expand the universe of “What’s Possible” for himself as a lawyer.

I’m thankful to him for reminding me that innovation is frequently not about invention as much as it is about adaptation and ingenuity. Which made me wonder: Can I apply some of that ingenuity to my own life and work? How can I use the wealth of tools available to me right now to become a more efficient, productive, and happier performer? Since watching Jack’s story, I’ve been considering major aspects of my workday, and trying to think boldly about how I might optimize them. Should I have my emails read to me? Should I find a method of commuting or tools to use during my commute that allow me to get vastly more work done before I arrive at my desk?

Interestingly, in the video, Jack explains that getting to work, for him, is like running ten miles before starting a marathon, noting that his cane provides only a four foot radius of information. Yet we already have driverless cars, high precision GPS (admittedly requiring satellite coverage), and similar active location technology, leading me to wonder how long it will be until that technology evolves and adapts to help people like Jack vastly expand their effective radius of information and reduce the effort it takes just to get to work.

### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
The questions, and the stakes, are heightened at the organizational level. Law firms that ask themselves how innovative they can be very well may reap the largest rewards in coming years. Historically, law firms have not been under great pressure, internally or externally, to work efficiently. But just as Jack Chen’s disability drove his pursuit of creative solutions, current conditions—including the aftermath of the recession, greater pricing pressure by corporate clients, and even the emergence of AI-driven legal solutions—are focusing law firms on the need to deliver more efficient services. Many firms are already benefiting from a focus on process improvement and Six Sigma management techniques.

Likewise, as leaders of one of the major vendors in the legal industry, my team and I often spend our time considering and developing (or acquiring) new inventions. But I wonder if we spend nearly enough time focusing on innovating through adaptation, through connecting existing technologies in new and more useful ways. Our heads of product and engineering regularly remind our team that there is often a simpler way to do something other than trying to build from scratch, and that existing tools can often be re-invented or re-imagined for other sources. Jack’s story is a powerful reminder of that.

But there is a long way to go. There is lots of ingenuity to apply within the walls of vendors, law firms, and others in the profession, with limited (or no) need for invention. There is much self-examination to be done, creativity to exercise, and breakthroughs to be made. Where is the fast-forward button that will allow lawyers and those who support them to achieve jaw-dropping levels of efficiency?

Jack Chen found his. And if any organization in our industry can approach his degree of success, it will be doing just fine.

Earlier: [Meet The Triathlon-Running, Kilimanjaro-Climbing Patent Lawyer Who Happens To Be Blind](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/09/meet-the-triathlon-running-kilimanjaro-climbing-patent-lawyer-who-happens-to-be-blind/)

David Perla is the President of Bloomberg Law and Bloomberg BNA’s Legal division. Perla plays a key leadership role in the continued growth of the company’s legal business, which includes legal, legislative, and regulatory news analysis and the flagship Bloomberg Law technology platform. # The Most Common Bad Question At Deposition Or Trial
## The double negatives mean that the questions and answers are generally useless.
By [Mark Herrmann](https://abovethelaw.com/author/mark-herrmann/)  
onApril 26, 2021 at 11:20 AM
21
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/04/the-most-common-bad-question-at-deposition-or-trial/&text=The%20Most%20Common%20Bad%20Question%20At%20Deposition%20Or%20Trial)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/04/the-most-common-bad-question-at-deposition-or-trial/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/04/the-most-common-bad-question-at-deposition-or-trial/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
What mistake do I often see even senior lawyers at good firms make when taking depositions or trying cases?

These folks know that questions on direct examination should be open-ended and questions on cross should be leading. I see people err in those regards, of course, but I don’t typically see experienced, knowledgeable folks make those errors.

Here’s the error I see all the time:

From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
Q: “You did not believe that the light was red, right?”

A: “No.” (And perhaps the witness is shaking his head while saying this.)

Or:

Q: “That is not your signature at the bottom of the document, right?”

A: “No.”

Everyone in the room understands that those “no” answers almost surely mean “yes.” The witness did not believe that the light was red, and the witness’ signature was not at the bottom of the document. But the double negative obscures this. It’s entirely conceivable that the “no” answers might in fact mean “no.”

The double negatives mean that the questions and answers are generally useless: The double negative obtained at deposition cannot be used on summary judgment because it’s ambiguous. Depending on what the video looks like, the double negative at deposition may not be useful for impeachment at trial. And the double negative at trial is similarly useless on appeal; the appellate panel, reading the transcript, will not be sure what the question and answer meant.

It’s true that the double negative conveys meaning in the moment: Everyone at the deposition or trial knows that the “no” answer means “yes.” That’s great — unless you were taking the deposition for a reason, such as setting up a summary judgment motion or creating useful material for impeachment at trial. And the ambiguity is fine at trial — so long as you win. If you happen to lose at trial, you don’t have the record you need for appeal.

It’s thus wrong to say, dismissively, as some do: “We all knew what the witness meant.”

From Pilot and Above The Law  
That’s true. You and the others in the room when the testimony was taken did know what the witness meant. But understanding the witness in the moment was not the only reason you were taking the testimony.

Good lawyers fix the double negative problem in one of three ways:

First, if a good lawyer realizes that he or she inadvertently put a negative in the question and obtained a negative response, the lawyer will immediately correct the error: “I’m sorry. I asked you a bad question, so the answer was confusing. What I said in the preceding question was correct, right?”

That will elicit either a “yes” or a “what was the question again?” that’s an invitation to fix the error.

Second, some lawyers strip the negative out of the question. Thus:

Q: “Did you believe the light was red?”

Or:

Q: “Is that your signature at the bottom of the document?”

The answers to those questions will be not be ambiguous.

But some lawyers tremble at the thought of the questions I’ve just suggested:  “Herrmann, you idiot! ‘Did you believe the light was red?’ is not a leading question. If you ask an open-ended question on cross-examination, you’ll get your ass handed to you. You must be a terrible lawyer!”

If asking those questions causes you too much stress, then you could use a third approach. Some lawyers fix the double negative problem by phrasing the questions slightly differently.

Q: “You did not believe that the light was red. Is that statement correct?”

Or:

Q: “That is not your signature at the bottom of the document.’ Is that statement correct?”

Those questions are likely to elicit the necessary “yes” or “yes, that’s correct.”

“Creating a useful record” and “having a conversation” are two entirely different things. If you’re doing the former, do not mistakenly think that you’re doing the latter. Is that correct?

Mark Herrmann spent 17 years as a partner at a leading international law firm and is now deputy general counsel at a large international company. He is the author of [The Curmudgeon’s Guide to Practicing Law](https://www.amazon.com/Curmudgeons-Guide-Practicing-Law/dp/1641054336/ref=pd_lpo_14_t_0/144-3788773-6854967?_encoding=UTF8&pd_rd_i=1641054336&pd_rd_r=61f38502-781d-47fb-a260-1970deea4a4d&pd_rd_w=AWqCy&pd_rd_wg=kFTh8&pf_rd_p=7b36d496-f366-4631-94d3-61b87b52511b&pf_rd_r=YK5GGKBGTD85BA2P42XB&psc=1&refRID=YK5GGKBGTD85BA2P42XB) and [Drug and Device Product Liability Litigation Strateg](http://www.amazon.com/Device-Product-Liability-Litigation-Strategy/dp/0198803532/ref=sr_1_fkmr0_1?keywords=%22drug+and+device+product+liability+litigation+strategy%22+second&qid=1578409788&s=books&sr=1-1-fkmr0)[y](http://www.amazon.com/Device-Product-Liability-Litigation-Strategy/dp/0198803532/ref=sr_1_fkmr0_1?keywords=%22drug+and+device+product+liability+litigation+strategy%22+second&qid=1578409788&s=books&sr=1-1-fkmr0) (affiliate links). You can reach him by email at [inhouse@abovethelaw.com](mailto:inhouse@abovethelaw.com).

# Ride 'Em, Cowboy! Top Texas Trial Firm Lassos Salary Raises For Associates
## Yet another firm has matched the Cravath MoneyLaw scale.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onJune 13, 2016 at 1:13 PMJune 13, 2016 at 1:14 PM
12
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/ride-em-cowboy-top-texas-trial-firm-lassos-salary-raises-for-associates/&text=Ride%20‘Em,%20Cowboy!%20Top%20Texas%20Trial%20Firm%20Lassos%20Salary%20Raises%20For%20Associates)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/ride-em-cowboy-top-texas-trial-firm-lassos-salary-raises-for-associates/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/ride-em-cowboy-top-texas-trial-firm-lassos-salary-raises-for-associates/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
The stars at night are big and bright deep in the heart of Texas — but they’re even bigger and brighter for law firm associates who’ve recently received news about their salaries skyrocketing. If you’re at a firm in the Lone Star State that’s been “monitoring” the market for further developments in this summer’s salary wars, bring to partners’ attention the fact that yet another firm has matched the [Cravath](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/breaking-ny-to-180k-cravath-raises-associate-base-salaries/) [MoneyLaw](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/what-firms-miss-the-moneylaw-cut/) scale.

On Thursday night, litigation boutique Yetter Coleman — a firm that previously started first-year associates at $170,000, a salary $10K above the then-prevailing market rate — announced that it was matching the new salary scale that’s taken the nation by storm. Yetter, one of the [top litigation firms by law school pedigree](https://abovethelaw.com/careers/top-litigation-firms-by-law-school-pedigree-2015/), notified associates that its goal was to remain competitive, attract top talent, and continue to be viewed as a top litigation boutique, and thus, firm leaders decided to adopt the new associate payscale. Sources tell us Yetter matched the Cravath scale at every level, through the class of 2008.

Congrats to all associates at Yetter Coleman, and keep on lassoing those trial victories!

# Morning Docket: 06.20.16
## * Friday was a relatively slow day for raises, with only six firms reporting for duty. We heard from [Katten](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/big-money-for-most-offices-smaller-money-for-one/), [Allen & Overy](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/another-magic-circle-firm-pulls-money-out-of-a-hat/), [WilmerHale](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/another-top-tier-firm-raises-salaries/), [King & Spalding](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/firm-with-big-profits-per-partner-shares-the-riches-in-new-york/), [Fish & Richardson](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/boston-based-law-firm-raises-salaries-for-all-offices/), and [Choate](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/firm-kicks-off-the-weekend-with-raises/). [[Above the Law / 2016 Salary Increase](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/2016-salary-increase/)] * Merrick Garland told some fifth graders the secret of success. But when they seemed boggled by "filibuster-proof majorities" he just told them to work hard. [[National Law Journal](http://www.nationallawjournal.com/home/id=1202760129543)] * Just another "lawyer bites man" story. [[Chicago Tribune](http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/local/breaking/ct-police-lawyer-bit-cop-resisted-arrest-20160618-story.html)] * Chocolate Deputy GC suspended for questioning the board. This may sound like one of those "right Twix, left Twix" commercials but it's real. [[Corporate Counsel](http://www.corpcounsel.com/id=1202760367629/Hershey-Deputy-GC-Remains-Suspended)] * Shameless bid to meet Leonardo DiCaprio via deposition moves forward. [[Law360](http://www.law360.com/newyork/articles/808358)] * New York votes to reform law that banned selling booze on Sunday mornings. I've actually never known a restaurant to respect the existing law, but good to know. [[CBS News](http://www.cbsnews.com/news/liquor-law-would-allow-new-yorkers-to-booze-earlier-with-sunday-brunch/)] * Controversy over the ALI. Somehow "wedgies" factor into this story. [[Verdict](https://verdict.justia.com/2016/06/20/increased-controversy-future-american-law-institute)]
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onJune 20, 2016 at 8:46 AM

# How A Top Personal Injury Lawyer Is Thriving In Today's Environment
## Here’s what a prominent firm learned this past year and how it’s positioned itself for success beyond the pandemic.
By Above The Law and Assembly Software  
onJune 10, 2021 at 1:13 PMJune 28, 2022 at 10:16 AM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/06/how-a-top-personal-injury-lawyer-is-thriving-in-todays-environment/&text=How%20A%20Top%20Personal%20Injury%20Lawyer%20Is%20Thriving%20In%20Today’s%20Environment)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/06/how-a-top-personal-injury-lawyer-is-thriving-in-todays-environment/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/06/how-a-top-personal-injury-lawyer-is-thriving-in-todays-environment/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
It’s no secret that, for personal injury firms, the pandemic has brought about a drop in new cases.

Amid this environment, however, some are taking steps to bolster their current operations and position themselves to emerge stronger than ever.

Hosted by legal tech journalist Bob Ambrogi, this webinar will focus on Paul Hernandez, Partner with Kalfus & Nachman and a well-known personal injury lawyer in Virginia, who will discuss how his firm has thrived in the past year and how it’s cultivating continued success in a new normal.

David Wagner, COO of Assembly Software, will join the panel to discuss the role of case management and offer other insights on how technology can help firms tightly manage profits at all times.

Join us June 29th at 2 p.m. ET / 11 a.m. PT for a lively discussion on:

- How firms can apply a metric-driven approach to managing costs and profitability
- The increased importance of frequent communication with clients and colleagues
- Managing firmwide productivity in light of the changing role of physical office space
- Increasing business development activity to secure a post-pandemic pipeline of cases
- How the right case management software can play a role in all of these areas
Fill out the form to register for the event. 

By filling out the form you are opting in to receive communication from Above the Law and its Partners.
####Topics
[Assembly Legal](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/assembly-legal/), [Assembly Software](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/assembly-software/), [Biglaw](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/biglaw/), [Small Law Firms](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/small-law-firms-topic/), [Sponsored Content](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/sponsored-content/), [Webinars](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/webinars/)

# Biglaw Firm Puts Some Extra Oomph Into Bonuses For High Billers -- We're Talking Above-Market Money!
## $45,000 over market? Yes, please!
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onDecember 8, 2021 at 3:57 PMDecember 8, 2021 at 4:14 PM
17
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/12/srz-bonus-2021/&text=Biglaw%20Firm%20Puts%20Some%20Extra%20Oomph%20Into%20Bonuses%20For%20High%20Billers%20—%20We’re%20Talking%20Above-Market%20Money!)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/12/srz-bonus-2021/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/12/srz-bonus-2021/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Picture this: You’ve been billing your butt off all year long, and when bonus time comes, you’re going to be expecting something big. Sure, that special bonus is nice, but you want more — much more. Fear not, because one law firm wants to give you that huge bonus you’ve been craving.

With a maximum bonus potential for senior associates of $183,000, Schulte Roth & Zabel came to play this bonus season. The firm — which brought in $444,700,000 gross revenue in 2020, putting it at No. 90 in the most recent Am Law 100 ranking — announced bonuses earlier this afternoon, and SRZ is offering much more than a simple Cravath/DPW match.

Schulte is also offering associates three levels of step-up bonuses as well as partial credit bonuses for those who were unable to meet their minimum hours. Here’s what the 2021 hours requirements are at the firm:

[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
1. In addition to the class bonus, and the previously announced special bonus, there will be another special bonus for all associates meeting the 2000 hour target.
2. There will also be three levels of step-up bonuses for 2300, 2500 and 2700 hours.
3. Associates with 1600 hours will receive a 50% class bonus and 50% special bonus. This will apply to the previously announced special bonus as well.
4. Associates with fewer than 1600 hours will receive a $5,000 bonus.

Without further ado, here’s the SRZ bonus scale for 2021:



All told, that’s a pretty penny over the market rate, depending on associate class year. That’s quite the thank you for the extra hard work associates have been putting in during the pandemic. Associates at the firm seem to be pretty happy about how their bonuses turned out.

Feedback from the associates seems to be really good.  The firm really came through on bonuses this year – above market for high billers, cushion for lower billers, and matching the DPW scale + special bonuses!!! SRZ has always tied bonuses to hours, which pays off when it’s this busy.  Lots of people definitely getting way above market comp.  Great way to end the year.

# Biglaw Firm Closes All Of Its Offices Across The Globe Due To Coronavirus Concerns
## What’s your firm doing to keep its lawyers and staff safe?
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onMarch 11, 2020 at 10:03 AMMarch 12, 2020 at 9:38 AM
109
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/03/faegre-drinker-worldwide-office-closure-coronavirus/&text=Biglaw%20Firm%20Closes%20All%20Of%20Its%20Offices%20Across%20The%20Globe%20Due%20To%20Coronavirus%20Concerns)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/03/faegre-drinker-worldwide-office-closure-coronavirus/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/03/faegre-drinker-worldwide-office-closure-coronavirus/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

(Image via Getty)

Earlier this week, [Quinn Emanuel shuttered its New York office](https://abovethelaw.com/2020/03/quinn-emanuel-new-york-coronavirus/) after one of the firm’s partners tested positive for coronavirus, enacting a work-from-home policy for all of its attorneys and staff members. Employees at other firms were shocked, and perhaps even envious, that such a successful firm had done such a thing, pondering if their own firms would ever close their doors to protect their health.

Now we know that at least one more firm is willing to close its doors to spare its employees from suffering through a COVID-19 diagnosis.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
Which Biglaw firm could it be?

Faegre Drinker, the 1,300-lawyer strong merger product of Faegre Baker Daniels and Drinker Biddle & Reath, decided to temporarily close all of its offices — every single one of them across the globe, 22 in total — due to coronavirus fears. That’s an incredibly bold move. The [American Lawyer](https://www.law.com/2020/03/10/faegre-drinker-closes-all-22-offices-after-potential-coronavirus-exposure/) has more information:

None of the firm’s lawyers and staffers have tested positive for the coronavirus, but a person who attended a recent event at Faegre Drinker’s Washington office did, the firm said in a statement. As a result, the firm’s executive leadership decided Monday to close the firm’s offices.

“Because the health and safety of our personnel and clients is our top priority, Faegre Drinker is temporarily closing its D.C. offices. As a measure of caution, our leadership team has also taken the step of closing our global offices on March 10 while we evaluate this situation,” the firm said in its statement.

The firm noted in its statement announcing the office closures en masse that its employees “are equipped with the required technology to work remotely and remain ready and available to assist clients.”

How long can a Biglaw firm survive with all of its employees working from home? We may soon find out, because Faegre Drinker has not said when it plans to reopen its offices across the globe. Stay tuned for further developments.

UPDATE (3/12/20): Faegre Drinker has since [reopened](https://www.law360.com/corporate/articles/1252464/faegre-drinker-reopens-most-offices-after-coronavirus-scare) the vast majority of its offices, save for its two outposts in Washington, D.C., where the potential coronavirus exposure began.

What is your firm doing to protect lawyers and staff from coronavirus? Please text us (646-820-8477) or [email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=Coronavirus%20Response) (subject line: “Coronavirus Response”). Stay safe.

# Class-Action Gender Discrimination Case Against Jones Day Dropped
## Plaintiffs' individual claims against the firm live on.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onDecember 16, 2020 at 4:16 PMDecember 16, 2020 at 2:50 PM
19
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/12/class-action-gender-discrimination-case-against-jones-day-dropped/&text=Class-Action%20Gender%20Discrimination%20Case%20Against%20Jones%20Day%20Dropped)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/12/class-action-gender-discrimination-case-against-jones-day-dropped/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/12/class-action-gender-discrimination-case-against-jones-day-dropped/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

Jones Day (Photo by David Lat)

Say goodbye to the class-action gender discrimination lawsuit against Jones Day.

As you may recall, [the purported class-action](https://abovethelaw.com/2019/12/plaintiffs-in-jones-day-gender-discrimination-case-want-it-to-be-a-class-action/?rf=1) gender discrimination [case](https://abovethelaw.com/2019/06/amended-gender-discrimination-case-brings-the-real-scoop-on-jones-day-compensation/) alleged a “fraternity culture” at the firm and unequal pay behind the firm’s notorious “[black box](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/the-jig-is-up-opening-up-jones-days-black-box/)” compensation system. The plaintiffs were spread throughout the country — Nilab Rahyar Tolton, Andrea Mazingo, Meredith Williams, and Jaclyn Stahl worked in California offices of the firm, while Saira Draper was an associate in Atlanta, and Katrina Henderson was in the firm’s New York office — and a core allegation is that the same black box compensation systems kept their pay below that of men working at the firm.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
After [contentious discovery](https://abovethelaw.com/2020/07/the-fight-to-crack-open-jones-days-black-box-heats-up/?rf=1), U.S. District Judge Randolph Moss of the District of Columbia ordered Jones Day to provide plaintiffs with salary information about every associate nationwide from 2012 to 2018. But that data didn’t turn out how the plaintiffs anticipated, and after an analysis, the plaintiffs have decided to drop the class-action claims against the Biglaw firm, as [reported by Law.com:](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2020/12/15/ex-jones-day-associates-drop-gender-bias-class-action-claims/)

In a joint [status report](https://beta.documentcloud.org/documents/20424229-toltonjonesday12142020) filed late Monday, attorneys for the six women suing the firm and for Jones Day indicated the women had decided to cast aside the class action claims after analyzing the nationwide evaluation and compensation data provided by the firm. They also agreed to drop their individual disparate impact claims related to the firm’s compensation model, while other individual claims will remain active.

Henderson, Draper, and Williams still have individual Equal Pay Act claims  and there are also pending claims under the California Private Attorneys General Act, Title VII of the Civil Rights Act, the Family and Medical Leave Act, and various state and District of Columbia laws.

Attorney for the plaintiffs, Sanford Heisler Sharp’s Deborah Marcuse, said they’ll continue to pursue their individual claims:

### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
“The six named plaintiffs brought this case in the name of transparency and equity in the legal profession and we will continue to vigorously pursue their compelling individual and statutory claims, including their individual claims of unequal pay.”

The firm’s statement on the latest development in the case noted the timing of the decision to drop the class-action claims and that they’ll continue to fight the individual claims:

Jones Day spokesman David Petrou noted that the women were required to submit expert reports in early December supporting their allegations that the firm’s evaluation and compensation processes led to systemic discrimination against women.

“But after their experts analyzed nationwide data for the period 2012–2018, they concluded—as Jones Day has said from the outset of the case’s filing—that there was no basis to pursue these claims,” he said in an email. “The firm will continue to litigate the limited—and equally meritless—claims that remain.”

It’s a quiet end to the class-action case we once hoped would blow open the firm’s notorious black box compensation system.

# Debevoise Makes Its Salary Announcement -- With A Twist
## Senior attorneys get a hefty raise.
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onJune 8, 2016 at 2:30 PM
12
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/debevoise-makes-its-salary-announcement-with-a-twist/&text=Debevoise%20Makes%20Its%20Salary%20Announcement%20—%20With%20A%20Twist)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/debevoise-makes-its-salary-announcement-with-a-twist/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/debevoise-makes-its-salary-announcement-with-a-twist/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
The cascade of salary matches — from [many firms, anyway](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/ny-to-180k-the-bad-news-who-wont-be-matching/) — keep on coming. Debevoise, being the venerable firm that it is, has matched the Cravath salary structure as expected.

But there is one twist to their memo that reflects a concern several tipsters have consistently raised with us throughout this process: what’s up with counsel? The senior attorneys floating just off the traditional grid have largely flown under the radar of these discussions, but Debevoise was good enough to place them front and center of their memo:



[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)

Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
Good for Debevoise. Counsel are people too!

Speaking of people, Debevoise didn’t forget its summer associate people either:



Congrats.

[Morning Docket](https://abovethelaw.com/morning-docket/)
# Morning Docket: 12.21.18
## * In completely unshocking news, despite advice from ethics officials, Acting Attorney General and former Tight End Matthew Whitaker has refused to recuse himself from oversight of special counsel Robert Mueller's Russian election interference probe. [[USA Today](https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2018/12/20/matthew-whitaker-cleared-oversee-robert-muellers-russia-probe/2374630002/)] * Corporate clients are trying to control their spending, and that means more and more Biglaw firms are having trouble collecting on their year-end bills, such that "on average [a firm] can lose 20 percent of its original billing amount." [[Big Law Business](https://biglawbusiness.com/slower-billing-collection-times-giving-law-firms-headaches)] * First-year law student enrollment increased by 3 percent this year, and two New Jersey schools played a really big role. Rutgers Law increased its 1Ls by 17.87 percent and Seton Hall Law increased its 1Ls by 24.87 percent. [[New Jersey Law Journal](https://www.law.com/njlawjournal/2018/12/20/law-schools-see-first-real-enrollment-gains-since-2010-399-19816/)] * Another day, another law school that's willing to accept the GRE for admissions. Starting this fall, the University at Buffalo School of Law will accept the alternative test in place of the LSAT to "eliminat[e] barriers to access to education." [[UB Now](http://www.buffalo.edu/ubnow/briefs/2018/12/law-school-gre.html)] * In case you missed it, earlier this week, Nick Wilson, a public defender, won the latest season of Survivor. Now the 2013 graduate of Alabama Law has $1 million to pay off his loans after becoming the Sole Survivor. Congratulations! [[Kentucky Today](http://kentuckytoday.com/stories/kentucky-lawyer-is-sole-survivor,16844)]
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onDecember 21, 2018 at 8:35 AMDecember 20, 2018 at 4:42 PM
9
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/12/morning-docket-12-21-18/&text=Morning%20Docket:%2012.21.18)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/12/morning-docket-12-21-18/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/12/morning-docket-12-21-18/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

# Boies Schiller Flexner Shakes Up Its Executive Committee
## Preparing for a firm without David Boies.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onJanuary 22, 2018 at 2:07 PM
0
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/01/boies-schiller-flexner-shakes-up-its-executive-committee/&text=Boies%20Schiller%20Flexner%20Shakes%20Up%20Its%20Executive%20Committee)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/01/boies-schiller-flexner-shakes-up-its-executive-committee/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/01/boies-schiller-flexner-shakes-up-its-executive-committee/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
I am certain the timing was coincidental. Yes, David Boies’s [representation of Harvey Weinstein](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/11/david-boies-takes-responsibility-for-enabling-harvey-weinstein/) and his involvement in the effort to squash a New York Times article about Weinstein’s alleged history of sexual assault and harassment has led to [severe backlash](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/11/new-york-times-fires-david-boies-over-the-whole-grave-betrayal-thing/) [against](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/11/david-boies-loses-more-work-over-weinstein-debacle/) the legal legend, but it is highly unlikely his Biglaw firm changed the way it operates as a direct result of the controversy.

That said, less than three months [since the scandal broke](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/12/david-boies-isnt-worried-about-recent-scrutiny/), Boies’s eponymous firm, Boies Schiller Flexner (BSF), has changed the composition of their executive committee (EC). As [reported](https://www.law.com/sites/americanlawyer/2018/01/19/changes-at-boies-schiller-as-firm-imagines-a-future-without-david-boies/) by Law.com, at BSF’s partnership meeting in December they increased the number of attorneys on the executive committee to 11 (up from 7). And the new — younger — EC now includes three women partners, [Karen Dunn,](https://www.bsfllp.com/lawyers/karen-l-dunn.html) [Natasha Harrison](https://www.bsfllp.com/lawyers/natasha-harrison.html) and [Karen Dyer.](https://www.bsfllp.com/lawyers/karen-c-dyer.html)

As the 77 year-old Boies paints it, this is all about smart succession planning (co-managing partner Jonathan Schiller is 71):

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)

In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
The firm is “making sure the next generation is not only ready to take over, but is in the process of taking over,” Boies said in an interview.

And Boies downplayed any conclusions one may draw from the timing of the decision:

Boies stressed that it would be “incorrect” to draw a line between the recent management changes and the Weinstein drama. The negative publicity over his Weinstein work hasn’t affected firm management, he said.

Long time clients support the move as a natural progression:

ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
“Even though David Boies has the energy of a 4-year-old, he is in the twilight of his career,” said Peter Carter, Delta Air Lines’ chief legal officer and executive vice president, who regularly hires Boies Schiller.

But it’s not as if Boies has already left the building, Carter and other clients said. The legendary litigator, who represented the prevailing plaintiffs for marriage equality at the U.S. Supreme Court and Al Gore in the disputed 2000 presidential election, still ranks as “the spiritual leader” of Boies Schiller, and “his fingerprints are all over that firm,” Carter said.

Of course none of this means Boies is stepping back from his role leading the firm. Also during the December meeting Boies was re-elected as firm chairman — a role he’s held since the founding of the firm.

# Firm Ignores Biglaw Special Bonus Trend, Gives Associates The Gift Of Takeout Food
## A nice gesture, but not what everyone was hoping for.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onApril 19, 2021 at 4:46 PMApril 19, 2021 at 3:41 PM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/04/firm-ignores-biglaw-special-bonus-trend-gives-associates-the-gift-of-takeout-food/&text=Firm%20Ignores%20Biglaw%20Special%20Bonus%20Trend,%20Gives%20Associates%20The%20Gift%20Of%20Takeout%20Food)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/04/firm-ignores-biglaw-special-bonus-trend-gives-associates-the-gift-of-takeout-food/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/04/firm-ignores-biglaw-special-bonus-trend-gives-associates-the-gift-of-takeout-food/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Listen, you can’t blame Biglaw associates for being antsy about bonuses. Special bonuses are sweeping their way through Biglaw firms, and if your firm *hasn’t* announced yet, well, you’re probs a bit nervous.

So, when folks at Quarles & Brady, a firm with $274,602,000 gross revenue in 2019 making it 118th on the Am Law 200, got an email from firm leadership advertising “a token of our appreciation,” well, you can’t be faulted for hoping for the best — a match of the special bonus numbers.

But alas, that wasn’t to be. Instead, it was a $30 voucher for GrubHub/UberEats.

[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
The nice thing is that the token of appreciation was sent to everyone, attorneys and staff. But as commentary from tipsters reveal, it hasn’t gone over well, with associates keeping their fingers crossed for special bonuses.

Coming in hot with a $30 Uber eats gift card for lawyers and staff after beating precovid revenue projections in FY20.

At least it’s better than a hat.

Yeah, [it’s not firm swag, so there’s that.](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/04/biglaw-firm-says-youre-expecting-a-bonus-but-please-accept-this-hat-instead/?rf=1)

Please help us help you when it comes to bonus news at other firms. If your firm given out bonuses or other “tokens” let us know! When your firm’s bonus memo comes out, please [email it to us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Bonus) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Bonus”) or text us (646-820-8477). Please include the memo if available. You can take a photo of the memo and send it via text or email if you don’t want to forward the original PDF or Word file.

And if you’d like to sign up for ATL’s Bonus Alerts, please scroll down and enter your email address in the box below this post. If you previously signed up for the bonus alerts, you don’t need to do anything. You’ll receive an email notification within minutes of each bonus announcement that we publish.

Feel free to email [her](mailto:kathryn@abovethelaw.com?subject=Your%20Column) with any tips, questions, or comments and follow her on Twitter ([@Kathryn1](https://twitter.com/Kathryn1)).

# Of Course Biglaw Firms That Conducted Layoffs Are Going To Hand Out Market Bonuses
## Come on, they can't afford to show weakness again.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onOctober 27, 2023 at 3:15 PMOctober 27, 2023 at 12:14 PM
3
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/10/of-course-biglaw-firms-that-conducted-layoffs-are-going-to-hand-out-market-bonuses/&text=Of%20Course%20Biglaw%20Firms%20That%20Conducted%20Layoffs%20Are%20Going%20To%20Hand%20Out%20Market%20Bonuses)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/10/of-course-biglaw-firms-that-conducted-layoffs-are-going-to-hand-out-market-bonuses/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/10/of-course-biglaw-firms-that-conducted-layoffs-are-going-to-hand-out-market-bonuses/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Ed. note: Welcome to our daily feature, [Quote of the Day](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/quote-of-the-day/).

Firms that were publicly in the news having done layoffs, I think they will be very sure to pay market bonuses.

— [Kate Reder Sheikh](https://www.mlaglobal.com/en/people/kate-reder-sheikh?byconsultantorauthor=kate-reder-sheikh), a California legal recruiter for Major, Lindsey & Africa, in comments given to [Bloomberg](https://news.bloomberglaw.com/business-and-practice/big-law-bonuses-holding-steady-but-now-come-with-more-strings) on Biglaw’s upcoming bonus seasons. Firms that [conducted layoffs and deferred incoming associates](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/layoffs/) earlier this year may be eager to show that they’re doing better now, but recall that many associates’ bonuses may be affected due to their [compliance with in-office attendance policies](https://abovethelaw.com/2023/08/biglaws-bad-ideas-4-day-office-mandates-and-attendance-based-bonus-policies/).

[Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/) is a senior editor at Above the Law, where she’s worked since 2011. She’d love to hear from you, so please feel free to [email](mailto:staci@abovethelaw.com) her with any tips, questions, comments, or critiques. You can follow her on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/stacizaretsky) and [Threads](https://www.threads.net/@stacizaretsky) or connect with her on [LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/in/staci-zaretsky).

# My Contract Is Due Yesterday
## Notes to my (legal) self.
By [Olga V. Mack](https://abovethelaw.com/author/olgamack/)  
onJune 23, 2023 at 3:22 PMJune 23, 2023 at 9:43 AM
9
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/06/my-contract-is-due-yesterday/&text=My%20Contract%20Is%20Due%20Yesterday)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/06/my-contract-is-due-yesterday/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/06/my-contract-is-due-yesterday/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))


Olga V. Mack is the VP at [LexisNexis](https://www.lexisnexis.com/) and CEO of [Parley Pro](https://parleypro.com/), a next-generation contract management company that has pioneered online negotiation technology. Olga embraces legal innovation and had dedicated her career to improving and shaping the future of law. She is convinced that the legal profession will emerge even stronger, more resilient, and more inclusive than before by embracing technology. Olga is also an award-winning general counsel, operations professional, startup advisor, public speaker, adjunct professor, and entrepreneur. She founded the [Women Serve on Boards](https://www.womenserveonboards.com/) movement that advocates for women to participate on corporate boards of Fortune 500 companies. She authored [Get on Board: Earning Your Ticket to a Corporate Board Seat](https://www.amazon.com/Get-Board-Earning-Ticket-Corporate/dp/1949991407), [Fundamentals of Smart Contract Security](https://www.amazon.com/Fundamentals-Smart-Contract-Security-Richard-ebook/dp/B07S8YF27G), and  [Blockchain Value: Transforming Business Models, Society, and Communities](https://www.amazon.com/Blockchain-Value-Transforming-Business-Communities/dp/1952538246). She is working on Visual IQ for Lawyers, her next book (ABA 2023). You can follow Olga on Twitter @olgavmack.

# Another Firm Bumps Associate Salaries To The $180K Scale
## We have our first Cravath match -- lock, stock, and barrel.
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onJune 6, 2016 at 8:28 PMJune 7, 2016 at 3:16 PM
41
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/another-firm-bumps-associate-salaries-to-match-180k-scale/&text=Another%20Firm%20Bumps%20Associate%20Salaries%20To%20The%20$180K%20Scale)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/another-firm-bumps-associate-salaries-to-match-180k-scale/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/another-firm-bumps-associate-salaries-to-match-180k-scale/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Well, that didn’t take long. About four and a half hours after we first learned that Cravath would [bump associate base salaries to $180K](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/breaking-ny-to-180k-cravath-raises-associate-base-salaries/), the tips started pouring in from California that litigation boutique [Hueston Hennigan](https://www.hueston.com/) matched the Cravath scale lock, stock, and barrel, in both its L.A. and Newport Beach offices.



Around the ATL office we’d mused that some firms might cynically boost first-year salaries to $180K while compressing salaries up the chain, but that’s certainly not the case here.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
Perhaps it’s not surprising that a firm born out of an [exodus over disappointing compensation](https://abovethelaw.com/2015/01/an-exodus-of-attorneys-out-of-irell-manella/) with a [history of beating Biglaw bonuses](https://abovethelaw.com/2015/12/associate-bonus-watch-another-boutique-beats-biglaw/) would be committed to staying on the cutting edge of salary.

Congratulations to the Hueston Hennigan associates!

Remember, when your firm matches, please text us (646-820-8477) or [email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Matches%20Cravath) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Matches Cravath”). Please include the memo if available. You can take a photo of the memo and send it via text or email if you don’t want to forward the original PDF or Word file.

Earlier: [Breaking: NY To $180K!!! Cravath Raises Associate Base Salaries!!!](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/breaking-ny-to-180k-cravath-raises-associate-base-salaries/)

[  ](/)	[Home](/) | [Archive](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/archive/) | [RSS](/feed/) | [Twitter](https://www.twitter.com/howappealing) | [Contact](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)

	

Sunday, January 22, 2017
“Foreign Payments to Trump Firms Violate Constitution, Suit Will Claim”: Eric Lipton and Adam Liptak of The New York Times have [this report](https://www.nytimes.com/2017/01/22/us/politics/trump-foreign-payments-constitution-lawsuit.html).

Posted at [9:52 PM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2017/01/22/#70215) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“Blankenship conviction upheld by appeals court”: Wendy Holdren of The Register-Herald of Beckley, West Virginia has [this report](http://www.register-herald.com/news/blankenship-conviction-upheld-by-appeals-court/article_2967d299-8191-5086-a647-826d8ef1d5a7.html) on [a ruling](http://www.ca4.uscourts.gov/Opinions/Published/164193.P.pdf) that the [U.S. Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit](http://www.ca4.uscourts.gov) issued Thursday.

Posted at [9:40 PM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2017/01/22/#70214) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“D.C. Circuit Review — Reviewed: ‘The U.S. Court of Appeals for the D.C. Circuit will be closed on . . . January 20, 2017.'” Aaron Nielson has [this post](http://yalejreg.com/nc/d-c-circuit-review-reviewed-the-u-s-court-of-appeals-for-the-d-c-circuit-will-be-closed-on-january-20-2017/) at the “Notice & Comment” blog of the Yale Journal on Regulation.

Posted at [9:20 PM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2017/01/22/#70213) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“GOP eyes new push to break up California court”: Lydia Wheeler of The Hill has [an article](http://thehill.com/regulation/court-battles/315354-gop-eyes-new-push-to-break-up-california-court) that begins, “Republican lawmakers are eyeing a new push to break up the California-based federal court of appeals, which is widely considered one of the most liberal courts in the country.”

Posted at [1:37 PM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2017/01/22/#70212) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“How Trump can use Obamacare to kill Obamacare: The same executive authority the Obama administration used to implement the law may now be used to dismantle it.” Dan Diamond of Politico.com has [this report](http://www.politico.com/story/2017/01/trump-obamacare-233983).

Posted at [1:08 PM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2017/01/22/#70211) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“Sen. Schumer willing to block Trump’s Supreme Court pick ‘if the nominee is not bipartisan and mainstream'”: Adam Edelman of The New York Daily News has [this report](http://www.nydailynews.com/news/politics/sen-schumer-block-trump-supreme-court-pick-article-1.2952895).

Eric Bradner of CNN.com reports that “[Schumer vows opposition to any ‘out of the mainstream’ Supreme Court pick](http://www.cnn.com/2017/01/22/politics/chuck-schumer-trump-cabinet/).”

And Mallory Shelbourne of The Hill reports that “[Schumer ready to leave Supreme Court seat open](http://thehill.com/homenews/senate/315524-schumer-ready-to-leave-ninth-supreme-court-seat-open).”

Posted at [12:58 PM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2017/01/22/#70210) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)

# 3 Reasons Not To Trust Personal Reviews
## Current and former employees make for unreliable reviewers because firms vary wildly from office to office, and from practice to practice.
By [Lateral Link](https://abovethelaw.com/author/lateral-link/)  
onOctober 11, 2019 at 4:16 PMOctober 11, 2019 at 4:42 PM
8
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/10/3-reasons-not-to-trust-personal-reviews/&text=3%20Reasons%20Not%20To%20Trust%20Personal%20Reviews)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/10/3-reasons-not-to-trust-personal-reviews/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/10/3-reasons-not-to-trust-personal-reviews/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

(Image via Getty)

You’ve found the perfect blackout curtains on Amazon, recommended specifically for overworked and late-sleeping New York associates, vampires, and Alaskans. They’re inexpensive and ship via Prime, but then you notice a wisp of yellow out of the corner of your eye that spells doom for your purchase: 3.5 stars. You click out of the product and start the cycle anew, maybe using the star filter this time. As technology has burgeoned over the last 20 years, anonymous or unknown reviewers have become more and more relied upon to shape our judgment in all aspects of our life. The idea of rating something is nothing new, but the proliferation of technology has allowed it to spread to even the most niche sectors. Law firms are one of the industries impacted by this rise in technology. Various sites and forums are devoted to the very task or rating firms. Why might this be problematic?

1) The Raters Are Overrated. We tend to be poor judges of our experiences, especially if we have limited context or reference points. What we may see as unreasonable, may be the norm for all employers in the industry — or vice versa. Regardless, we are prone to black and white thinking. Distributions of reviews tends towards bimodal distributions of reviews at one-star and five-star reviews. Furthermore, interpersonal factors have the largest correlation between good and bad reviews. One explanation for this is that overwhelming positive or negative experiences motivate us to actually review a product or company. [Research shows ](http://www.columbia.edu/~on2110/Papers/Schoenmueller_netzer_stahl_2018.pdf)that the more someone reviews, the more evenly distributed their reviews tend to be. When it comes to law firms, most reviewers have only practiced at a few firms and have limited comparison points.

Moreover, what exactly are we rating? The discrete parts that make up an overall review may be composed of completely different categories based on who you ask and are more a reflection on their values. If you value work-life balance, you may give a sweltering New York litigation powerhouse a one-star review based on your unhappiness with firm’s encroachment into your personal life. Others who thrive in pressure cookers might find the firm perfectly aligns with their preferences. If we look even more granularly, we see another reason why current and former employees make for unreliable reviewers.

2) A Rose Is Not A Rose Is Not A Rose. Overall firm reviews reside in a vacuum, stripped from the individual components that are summed to generate that rating. The problem with this is that firms vary wildly from office to office, and from practice to practice. The experience of working as an associate at one firm in New York could be diametrically different to the experience of working in their San Francisco office. Even going up one floor in the same office, you may find the real estate practice to have a completely different atmosphere compared to your corporate practice. The experience is somewhat akin to college, where your grade and interest in your class largely depends on the professor teaching. Ultimately, the firm decides who to hire and sets the tone for corporate culture. As firms expand, this becomes harder to instill and police and sometimes incongruent attorneys slip in through the cracks — or the prospective bottom-line boost is enough to discount or ignore red flags. I cannot recount how many times I’ve heard: “The firm would be perfect, if only I didn’t have to work for this partner.” However, basing a lateral decision on firm personnel can lead to another complication.

3) As Constant As A Northern Star. It will come as no shock to you, that attorneys like to move around firms. The constant churn muddies the waters and can make it difficult to get an accurate read on a firm. The friend who told you not to move to her former firm because of the cantankerous rainmaker who made her life hell may be surprised to find out that the rainmaker is now on a permanent golf tour across the world. Associates tend to lateral every three years on average, while partners tend to stay a little bit longer, hanging on for five years. Since the composition of firms is changing so often, there are really only a few sources of information that can give you an unbiased and accurate view of the current market.

If you haven’t guessed it already, one is legal recruiters. We talk to thousands of people every year from attorneys to firm chairs, and have our finger constantly on the pulse of the market so that we can guide our candidates to the firm that makes aligns with all of their personal and professional needs. Using a source like Vault or the U.S. News and World Report can be tricky when assessing a prospective employer. For other industries, the resources available and corporate culture largely dictate your experience in the company. However, because law firms are more decentralized and have access to largely the same resources, your local practice bubble will largely dictate whether you have a positive or negative experience. Rather than relying on outdated information, feel free to contact [me](https://www.laterallink.com/team/michael-allen/) or my [f](http://laterallink.com/team)[ellow colleagues at Lateral Link](http://laterallink.com/team) if you are interested in making a lateral move, armed with up to date and accurate information. Feel free to rate your current firm below and we’ll post the results next week and break down our observations.

[ Create your own user feedback survey ](https://www.surveymonkey.com)
Ed. note: This is the latest installment in a series of posts from [Lateral Link’s ](http://bit.ly/2b4rW3j)team of expert contributors. [Michael Allen](https://www.linkedin.com/in/michaelallen/) is the CEO of Lateral Link. He is based in the Los Angeles office and focuses exclusively on Partner and General Counsel placements for top firms and companies. Prior to founding Lateral Link in 2006, he worked as an attorney at both Gibson, Dunn & Crutcher LLP and Irell & Manella LLP. Michael graduated summa cum laude from the University of California, San Diego before earning his JD, cum laude, from Harvard Law School.

With over 14 offices world-wide, Lateral Link specializes in placing attorneys at the most prestigious law firms and companies in the world. # You Are Not Alone In Your Hatred Of The Biglaw Life
## 'It feels like my eight-year legal joyride earned me a top position as a corporate chauffeur.'
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onMarch 10, 2017 at 3:29 PM
10
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/03/you-are-not-alone-in-your-hatred-of-the-biglaw-life/&text=You%20Are%20Not%20Alone%20In%20Your%20Hatred%20Of%20The%20Biglaw%20Life)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/03/you-are-not-alone-in-your-hatred-of-the-biglaw-life/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/03/you-are-not-alone-in-your-hatred-of-the-biglaw-life/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
I do not enjoy my job. I detest the obligation to keep track of my time in billable six-minute increments and the enormous pressure to work as many of those increments as is humanly possible. Worse, I work as a junior member on teams of lawyers assembled to produce work I used to complete alone in less time. As far as I can tell, this arms race approach to litigation adds bureaucratic and political complexities while degrading the quality of the work we produce. In all events, my job bears little resemblance to my previous professional experiences, the ones that purportedly made me such an attractive hire. It feels like my eight-year legal joyride earned me a top position as a corporate chauffeur.

— [Isaac Lidsky](https://twitter.com/isaaclidsky), a [former child star](http://www.imdb.com/name/nm0509240/) who graduated from Harvard Law School and in 2008 became the first blind Supreme Court clerk, [reflecting on his unhappy time](http://www.law.com/sites/almstaff/2017/03/09/with-eyes-wide-open-blind-lawyer-recounts-scotus-clerkship-unhappy-law-firm-life/) at the Biglaw firm of Akin Gump. He left Biglaw in 2011, but the experience provides plenty of fodder in his [new book](http://www.lidsky.com/book/), [“Eyes Wide Open”](http://amzn.to/2nnByc4) (affiliate link).

# NYC Biglaw Associates Don't Seem Too Thrilled About 'Flexible' Office Return Policies
## Some of these policies aren't flexible at all, and associates aren't very happy about it.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onMay 2, 2022 at 4:46 PMMay 2, 2022 at 3:26 PM
17
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/05/nyc-biglaw-associates-dont-seem-too-thrilled-about-flexible-office-return-policies/&text=NYC%20Biglaw%20Associates%20Don’t%20Seem%20Too%20Thrilled%20About%20‘Flexible’%20Office%20Return%20Policies)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/05/nyc-biglaw-associates-dont-seem-too-thrilled-about-flexible-office-return-policies/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/05/nyc-biglaw-associates-dont-seem-too-thrilled-about-flexible-office-return-policies/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
With rents in Manhattan at a 33% increase, it’s absurd to expect us to be in the city for a job that could be done remotely without giving us a 33% salary bump.

— An anonymous Davis Polk associate’s response to a survey concerning [Biglaw firms’ return-to-office policies](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2022/05/02/remote-or-hybrid-light-the-differences-matter-to-attorneys-and-should-to-firms/) in our “post”-pandemic world. Davis Polk recently announced its own office-return policy, [mandating three days of in-office work](https://abovethelaw.com/2022/04/top-biglaw-firm-returns-to-the-office-with-mandatory-tuesday-thursday-attendance/) each week on Tuesdays, Wednesdays, and Thursdays. The associate said the policy impacted their decision to explore lateral possibilities. Along the same lines, Milbank has asked associates to work in the office three days each week, and an anonymous associate said that while the [policy was “reasonable,” it was not “ideal.”](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2022/05/02/remote-or-hybrid-light-the-differences-matter-to-attorneys-and-should-to-firms/) “I would gladly move to any firm paying associates the market rate if they would allow me to work 100% remotely,” they said.

[Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/) is a senior editor at Above the Law, where she’s worked since 2011. She’d love to hear from you, so please feel free to [email](mailto:staci@abovethelaw.com) her with any tips, questions, comments, or critiques. You can follow her on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/stacizaretsky) or connect with her on [LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/in/staci-zaretsky).

####Topics
[Biglaw](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/biglaw/), [COVID-19](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/covid-19/), [Hybrid Work Policies](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/hybrid-work-policies/), [Law Firm Reopenings](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/law-firm-reopenings/), [Quote of the Day](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/quote-of-the-day/), [Work From Home Policies](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/work-from-home-policies/)

# Biglaw Suffers Huge Blow In Malpractice Case Against Horrible Person
## Expert testimony dominates most malpractice suits. Why not legal malpractice suits?
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onAugust 7, 2018 at 5:15 PMAugust 7, 2018 at 4:37 PM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/08/biglaw-suffers-huge-blow-in-malpractice-case-against-horrible-person/&text=Biglaw%20Suffers%20Huge%20Blow%20In%20Malpractice%20Case%20Against%20Horrible%20Person)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/08/biglaw-suffers-huge-blow-in-malpractice-case-against-horrible-person/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/08/biglaw-suffers-huge-blow-in-malpractice-case-against-horrible-person/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
With football season around the corner, it’s time to remember what a magnificent waste of carbon Daniel Snyder is. He’s the sort of guy who can own the most notoriously racist caricature in sports and also fairly, yet completely unironically, accused a newspaper’s cartoon of him as “racist.” Thankfully, he’s also the sort of guy whose sheer incompetence keeps his team an also-ran, proving there is some general thrust of karma out there.

Snyder is also at the center of a $22 million legal malpractice claim against Cadwalader, alleging that the firm gave him bad advice on an investment bank’s fee during a proxy fight. The agreement supposedly capped the bank’s fees at $2 million, but the bank later challenged the agreement and managed to win $10 million.

If that sounds like a complex legal question fraught with competing interpretations — you know, the sort of high stakes, nuanced question that might lead someone to hire Cadwalader in the first place — then Cadwalader, and their attorneys from Cravath, agree with you. That’s why they argued that they should be able to call a number of esteemed legal experts to testify as to the reasonableness of Cadwalader’s conduct. Snyder’s people disagreed.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
Manhattan Supreme Court Justice O. Peter Sherwood agreed with Snyder. From [New York Law Journal](https://www.law.com/newyorklawjournal/2018/08/07/judge-dings-cadwalader-defense-before-legal-malpractice-trial/):

With a jury trial scheduled to start next month, Manhattan Supreme Court Justice O. Peter Sherwood said there are only two versions of the facts” regarding events 13 years ago that may have resulted in injury to Red Zone — “neither of which involve matters outside the ken of the typical juror.”

In breaking news, the “typical juror” in Sherwood’s experience is a Harvard-educated attorney. Now expert legal testimony is always dicey, coming as close as it does to usurping the judge’s role as the one who dictates the meaning of the law to the jury. But malpractice hinges on whether or not the professional performed their job reasonably, which can only be sussed out through expert professional testimony. No one’s forcing a doctor to weather a medical malpractice claim without expert testimony; why in the world would attorneys in a complex transaction not be afforded the same courtesy?

But here we are. Daniel Snyder’s going to finagle his way to success in this one, isn’t he? At least Washington’s going to tank again.

# Top 50 Biglaw Firm Gets Brand New Office Out Of Group Lateral Hire
## That's one way to open a new office.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onJune 17, 2022 at 12:42 PMJune 17, 2022 at 2:04 PM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/06/top-50-biglaw-firm-gets-brand-new-office-out-of-group-lateral-hire/&text=Top%2050%20Biglaw%20Firm%20Gets%20Brand%20New%20Office%20Out%20Of%20Group%20Lateral%20Hire)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/06/top-50-biglaw-firm-gets-brand-new-office-out-of-group-lateral-hire/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/06/top-50-biglaw-firm-gets-brand-new-office-out-of-group-lateral-hire/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
What’s the best way to open a new office in a market where there’s a great amount of demand? If you’re a high-powered Biglaw firm, you may find the answer in the latest lateral trend of big group moves. That’s what just happened at Holland & Knight, and the firm now has 17 new lawyers and a second Los Angeles office to show for it.

Holland & Knight — currently ranked at No. 33 on the Am Law 100, having brought home $1,402,502,000 gross revenue in 2021 — just absorbed lawyers from Pircher, Nichols & Meeks, a California real estate firm. The move is not being characterized as a merger, but rather, a big group hire.

Another Biglaw firm, White & Case, tried to make merger moves with Pircher in the past, but the firm turned the possibility down, opting instead to “remain a competitive boutique firm.” Why the change of heart? H&K is apparently a “much better fit.” [Reuters](https://www.reuters.com/legal/legalindustry/holland-knight-gets-new-la-office-by-absorbing-real-estate-law-firm-2022-06-16/) has additional details:

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
Tampa-founded Holland & Knight, which combined last summer with Dallas-based Thompson & Knight, will take over Pircher’s lease in Century City, a business district in Los Angeles. Holland & Knight also has an office in downtown Los Angeles, and two others in California. …

Holland & Knight says its real estate section has about 300 lawyers nationally. [Joseph] Guay, the [real estate] department leader, said the practice had its “best year ever” in 2021. With uncertainty ahead in the market with rising interest rates and inflation, the new team coming in can help as real estate clients may have to “pivot,” he said.

Is your Biglaw firm considering any massive lateral hires? That seems to be the way of the future when it comes to bringing in new talent.

[17-Lawyer Group Joins Holland & Knight in SoCal, as Real Estate Practices See High Demand](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2022/06/16/17-lawyer-group-joins-holland-knight-as-real-estate-practices-see-high-demand/) [American Lawyer]
[Holland & Knight gets new LA office by absorbing real estate law firm](https://www.reuters.com/legal/legalindustry/holland-knight-gets-new-la-office-by-absorbing-real-estate-law-firm-2022-06-16/) [Reuters]

# The Pandemic's Impact On The Legal Industry (Through April)
## The U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics says what we all know is true.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onMay 12, 2020 at 2:14 PMMay 12, 2020 at 1:43 PM
12
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/05/the-pandemics-impact-on-the-legal-industry-through-april/&text=The%20Pandemic’s%20Impact%20On%20The%20Legal%20Industry%20(Through%20April))[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/05/the-pandemics-impact-on-the-legal-industry-through-april/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/05/the-pandemics-impact-on-the-legal-industry-through-april/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
If you’re a regular reader of Above the Law, you will not be shocked to learn that COVID-19 has had a tremendous impact on the legal industry. Damn near every day we are reporting on layoffs or furloughs or salary cuts or some other austerity measure designed to help firms maintain cash flow and navigate these uncertain times.

The latest [jobs report](https://www.bls.gov/news.release/empsit.nr0.htm) from the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics actually quantifies what even casual observers of the industry know is true — that the legal profession has lost a hella lot of jobs because of the coronavirus. According to BLS, there was a net loss of 64,000 jobs in the legal sector, bringing the total number of jobs in the industry down to 1,097,006. The April report also had updated stats for March, showing 1,700 legal sector jobs were lost that month.

Of course, it isn’t just the legal industry that has taken a hard hit during these tumultuous times. There have been massive job losses across the nation in all industries, a figure BLS puts at 20 million jobs lost in April. And unemployment rose by 10.3 percent, which is the largest monthly increase since January 1948, when records started being kept.
